14.content:
Julian walked alone along the beach, wearing his red and black swimming trunks and flip-flops, kicking the white sand with his feet, frustrated. He had always hated being the youngest in the family, but it really sucked today. His parents were back at the resort lying down and "sunning" next to the pool, his sister had gone off scuba diving, and his three brothers had taken off on their own adventure (Julian was pretty sure they were trying to find someplace that would serve them alcohol). He wanted to do something, anything, with any of them, but he couldn't: the pool his parents were at was adults-only, the scuba company required anyone using their equipment to be at least sixteen and put a $100 deposit down, and his brothers wouldn't let him come along cause he was "a little kid". All he could do today was walk along this beach, bored and wishing he was back home with his friends, or that his friends were here with him. Alone as a twelve-year-old, Hawaii kinda sucked.

Even the beach, the thing he was looking forward to the most before the trip started, was sort of a drag. He wanted to go swimming, but his parents specifically told him not to go into the ocean without them or one of his siblings around. He thought about disobeying and going anyway, but he feared what would happen if he got caught: he would be grounded until he turned eighteen, have his allowance revoked permanently, or any one of dozens of other equally severe punishments. Even if he didn't get caught, he knew enough about rip-tides and strong currents to know it wasn't a good idea to go without someone he knew. He had thought about trying to build a sand-castle, but that seemed like a little kiddie thing (at least his brothers had said so the other day), and besides, the sand wasn't stable enough on this beach for that to be successful.

As he looked out at the crowds, the group of twenty-somethings playing beach-volleyball, the old ladies looking for seashells, and the families horsing around and having a good time, Julian cursed to himself. "Fuckin' family. Why can't I be like one of these kids and have parents and brothers and sisters who want to do stuff together?" Disgusted by the crowds (or rather, by how lonely they made him feel), he headed away from the resort areas, down to a more private part of the beach.

He had to hike a bit to get away from the din of the crowds, but when he finally got to a secluded area where no one else was around, he sat down and looked out onto the waters. The waves rose high above the surface, crashing onto the beach, then being pulled back out and doing the whole thing over again. "At least this is pretty peaceful," he said to himself. As the minutes passed by, he slowly began to let free his stress, and he felt a little better about the day.

Watching the waves, Julian saw something get washed up onto the shore about a hundred yards from him, glistening in the sun. He wasn't sure what it was, but it looked interesting enough to warrant further attention, so he got up and jogged over to investigate. When he got within thirty feet, he determined it was a rather large bottle of some sort, perhaps a wine bottle or something similar.

Once he got to the bottle, he picked it up and tried to make out what was inside. The glass was greenish and translucent, and he could make out what looked like a piece of paper as well as a large, somewhat heavy circular object. His curiosity piqued, he ran to the edge of the beach where some boulders stood. Raising the bottle high above his head, he smashed it down onto the rock, sending the glass shattering but freeing the contents.

The circular object turned out to be some sort of pendant with a thin ribbon threaded through it, sort of like the medals given out at the Olympics. He picked it up and examined it closely. By color, at least, it looked like it had been made of gold, but it felt surprisingly lightweight. One side was completely smooth, while the other side had an engraved picture of an arm flexing.

"What in the world is this?" he asked aloud. Picking up the paper, he examined it for answers. The writing on it was very faded, but still seemed to be legible. In ornate script, it read: "When you wear this pendant, it can provide you with seemingly unlimited power, and whatever you wish becomes truth. But beware: power comes with a price. It has caused our people too much havoc and distress. I hope you find it more beneficial than we did."

"Seemingly unlimited power?" Julian repeated aloud. This was too good to be true. It definitely sounded like someone was playing a prank on him; that he'd try it out and someone would come out of the water or behind a palm tree and laugh at him, or worse. He started to throw it back to the ground, but before he could, he thought: "What if…" What if it were true? What if, somehow, this would be his ticket to changing his life? It was a ludicrous and entirely unrealistic idea, he knew, but he had always had an active imagination, so part of him wanted to believe that it might, just might, be real. Besides, he couldn't help but thinking that if he didn't try it out, he'd spend the rest of his life wondering about it.

Shaking his head and quieting the voice inside telling him he was being childish, he still knew he just had to try. "It can't hurt," he reasoned. He put the ribbon around his neck and let the pendant fall to his bare chest, jumping in shock as he did so. Whereas it felt somewhat cold and metallic in his hands, against his chest it felt warm, almost as if something inside it had caused it to start emitting heat. "Must be the Hawaii sun," he said.

He thought about how to use it. "Whatever you wish becomes truth," he repeated from the paper. "I guess I should test it out with something small first." Looking around, the only thing on the horizon that caught his eye was the shards of glass from the bottle he had broken. "That should do," he said to himself. "Okay, I guess I just have to say it aloud." He cleared his throat. "I… I wish this bottle was whole again."

At first it looked like nothing had happened, and Julian closed his eyes, shaking his head in disappointment. When he opened them, however, he was shocked to see that the bottle had been completely restored to its former unbroken state! Rubbing his eyes in disbelief, he looked back only to see, sure enough, the bottle was still there. As he examined the ground closer, he noticed there wasn't a shard of glass anywhere to be found. Somehow, someway, the bottle had been fixed.

"Oh my god," he said. "The pendant works!"

He had to test it out on something else to be sure. It might have been a fluke, and besides, the bottle was an inanimate object. Julian knew that the only way he would believe in the pendant's power was if he tried it out on himself. He thought for a second of what he should try, then came to a decision. Taking a deep breath, he whispered aloud, "I wish I was six inches taller."

After a moment, he felt his entire body begin to tingle, and he noticed his swimming trunks were beginning to feel more restrictive. Looking down, he saw the ground getting further and further away, and his torso and legs were lengthening, stretching out, almost like putty but more firm. "Holy crap!" he said aloud as the tingling stopped, his trunks stretched nearly skin-tight against his legs and crotch. "I… I can't believe it!" He couldn't quite tell how much taller he had grown, but it was significant. He felt that he was nearly as tall as his 14-year-old brother Christian.

Growing so quickly felt amazing, but Julian wanted to see if he could reverse it, to make sure that if anything ever got out of hand he'd have a failsafe. With a slight bit of disappointment in his voice, he said, "I wish to cancel the last wish." Instantly, without any kind of sensation or sudden rush, he felt shorter, and his swimming trunks returned to their normal loose fit. "Huh," he mused aloud, "I guess reversing a wish is quicker than making the wish in the first place. Interesting."

All sorts of possibilities of how to use the pendant rushed through his mind. He could change himself in any way imaginable, or mess with his family, or even have some fun with his friends back home. As he thought of these things, he realized something. With this pendant, his power seemed truly limitless. With this pendant, he was a god.

A wry smile formed across Julian's face. Hawaii wasn't going to be so boring after all.

The pendant around his neck, Julian hurried back over to the packed beach, thinking about all the things he could do now that he had this power. Part of him wanted to make drastic, massive changes right away, totally conforming the world to his will and whim, but Julian shook those feelings off, remembering the words on the paper that came with the pendant: "Power comes with a price". Even if he had almost-unlimited abilities, he didn't want to overuse them. As angry as he had been with his family before, this discovery had overcome all that, and he knew he had to be responsible.

Once he got to the middle of the crowds, he slowed his jog to a steady walk, looking around for the first interesting thing he could test out. His eyes landed on a red-haired, pale-skinned boy a little younger than him who was playing in the ocean a few dozen yards from where he stood, running out and getting his feet wet, then retreating back gleefully when a large wave would come in. Julian recognized that this boy had just checked into the same floor of the hotel that Julian's family was. He hadn't really had much interaction with the boy, only seeing him in passing in the hall once and a couple of times down in the lobby. He didn't even know the boy's name; all he knew was that he was from England, and he spoke with a thick British accent.

"He's so fair-skinned," Julian said to himself, "he'll get completely destroyed by the harsh sun here." His hand brushed against the pendant and he smiled. "Maybe I can help that!" He took a deep breath. This would be the first time he had changed a person other than himself, so he didn't know what variables would come into play. "At least it'll just be a small change. I wish for that red-haired English boy to get a nice, even bronze tan."

After a second, the boy's skin started to glow, as more and more melanin started to appear, his skin gradually growing darker. It was quite a sight to see, this boy going from extremely pale to tan so quickly, and Julian's eyes widened as he watched, even though he knew it was coming. Julian looked at the people near the boy, and no one else seemed to be reacting or paying any attention to the change that was occurring. Even the boy didn't notice his skin becoming more and more brown. "Maybe people are oblivious to my changes unless I specifically wish them to notice…" Julian guessed, "…if I can even wish for that."

Ten or fifteen seconds later, the changes seemed to have stopped, the boy's skin now a healthy tanned light-brown, giving him a much more Mediterranean look. The only thing that indicated his previous skin color was his shock of bright-red hair, which now looked kind of ridiculous and out of place in comparison to his tan, but Julian found it kinda neat-looking. The boy still had the same gleeful expression, and the same playfulness to him, he just looked more appropriate for Hawaii now. The rest of his family that were nearby still had their fair complexion, and Julian held his breath as the boy's mother, a short, squat woman, walked over to her son.

"Harry," she called out, "we're all putting on some more suncream now. C'mon, Love, get out of the water."

"But mum," the boy replied, "I feel fine!"

The woman sighed, shaking her head. "I guess you can skip this round. I don't know how you got lucky enough to be born with such sun-proof skin."

The woman turned and walked back to where the rest of the family was sitting, while the boy squealed gleefully as he continued to splash in the waves. Julian sighed in relief, realizing that his first test of the Pendant on another person was a complete success. He also felt a little thrill from helping someone else out, even a stranger. "This is so cool," he whispered. "I'm almost like a super-hero." A smile came to his lips he thought about what to do next.

I know, based on how much you like the idea of clothing ripping to shreds, that's a switch you'll probably enjoy playing with." Kuai chuckled at this.

"Now, you can turn any of these switches on or off at any time, just by bringing up this screen with a double-click of that button. Any switch you change will not be retro-active, meaning that if you want to undo something you did, you need to make sure the switches affecting people's memories are turned on, otherwise, they'll still remember the changes you made., and if you grow somebody and cause the building they're in to grow because of it, if you turn off the switch and shrink the person back down, you'll still be left with a huge building. Got it?"

Kuai nodded, giving each switch on the screen a little tap, flicking them on and off. When he was finished, he made sure they were back on their defaults, saying, "Got it." As he flicked the last switch, he noticed a long slider bar at the bottom of the screen below all the switches. "Hey, Nick," he asked. "What's the long red bar at the bottom do?" He heard hesitation come from Nick's end, with a long pause. "Nick, c'mon. I'm your closest friend. Tell me."

Finally, Nick answered, "That's the slider to override the safety protocols. It'll ask you for a passcode to do so, and I can't give you that, Kuai, I just can't."

Kuai sighed. "I understand, Nick," he said, accepting it, but a little hurt that his friend wouldn't give him the information.

"Hey, don't be disappointed. There's only a few things that the safety protocols control that affect you. First off, and I know this sounds like a biggie, but whoever's wearing the pendant can't change themselves. If I know you, though, I don't think that's gonna matter much. Am I right?"

Grinning, Kuai answered, "Sure, Nick. That's fine. What else?"

"Well, the only other thing is that there's a limit to how much you can change someone. It varies from subject to subject and in different situations, but there might come a time that you won't be able to grow or transform a subject anymore without taking them back to normal. If that seems to be coming too early or too soon, let me know, and I might be able to log-in remotely and adjust some of the parameters."

"Okay," Kuai said. "Anything else I should know?"

"That's about it." Nick chuckled slightly. "I know you're gonna have a lot of fun with it tomorrow at school with your students, big guy. Make sure you call me and let me know all the details."

"Will do," Kuai smiled, excited about all the possibilities that were in store for him. "I'll talk to you tomorrow then. And, thank you so much for this. It means a lot you shared this with me."

"Don't mention it, big guy. You deserve it."

"Bye, Nick."

"Bye," Nick repeated, then hung up.

That night, Kuai couldn't sleep much, too excited, both in his head and elsewhere, for what the next day would hold. When his alarm rang in the morning, he jumped out of bed, into a quick shower and shave, and after eating breakfast, he was on the road to the school. After getting his lesson plans finalized for the day, the first bell rang, and the students filed into his classroom.

His first class was 7th grade Honors Pre-Algebra, and it was a small class, consisting of ten girls and six boys. Kuai looked at each of the new students as they walked in, each one nervous and excited at the start of a new school year, with new books, fresh backpacks, and clean uniforms, friends to make and experiences to have. As they all took their seats, Kuai fingered the pendant. Finally, he made sure it was in the 'invisible' mode so no one could see it, draped it around his neck, and then stood up, ready to face the class.
1511.title: Training

choices: Change another student next period with one or more of the settings off
Find Kevin again later in the day and keep experimenting with him
15111.content:
Classroom management on the first day of school is easy. Let the children see no fear and they will usually leave you alone. Kuai’s classroom was no exception. Just seeing his towering 6’9”, heavily muscled physique was usually enough to keep the students in line. With a stern but smooth tone, Kuai stared down at his class, absorbing every face as fast as he could.

“Welcome to Honor’s Pre-Algebra. I am Mr. Tao, and let me start off by saying that if you want to succeed in my class, you will have to work for it. Your butts will be in those chairs before the bell stops ringing, you will always bring a pencil and---“ pause for dramatic effect, “—I accept no excuses.”

Silence filled the room. Kuai could literally hear a few of the student’s gulp with anxiousness. Kuai was actually a pretty easy going guy when it came to everything (but sports). He liked to have fun and he loved life. But teaching is all about presence and theater. Even he knows that his enormous body won’t control the masses forever if he doesn’t have the vibrato to back it up.

He followed up by calling the roll and having the students introduce themselves. Each time he made it to one of the boys, he would study them very carefully, instantly exploring all of the possibilities with his pendant. Out of the six, one immediately caught his attention.

A taller, lanky boy stood up in the third row. His beautiful green eyes were enlarged over twice their size because of the coke bottle lenses they hid behind. He had tan skin with short brown hair and spoke with a mousy voice. “Hey. I’m K-Kevin.” He was clearly nervous. “I’m in the seventh grade—ob-obviously, and I—enjoy reading and playing Call of Duty.”

Something about the boy stuck with Kuai. Perhaps, it was because Kevin never took his eyes off of him. His coke bottle glasses made that painfully obvious. Every time Kevin thought Kuai was looking the boy would blink a lot or hide his eyes in the rims of his glasses. Kuai though this was cute and saw lots of potential there. Kevin remained slouched in his chair and tried to “hide” behind his glasses. But he knew this kid was very interested in what he saw.

RIIING!

“—and I will expect you all with books and section one homework on my desk tomorrow.”

All of the students quickly filled out of his room, erupting in louder conversations the moment they went through the doorway. The only student who remained behind was Kevin. He was still slouched in his chair pretending not to stare at Kuai.

“Did you need something?” Kuai softened his voice for Kevin. He didn’t need to command a room anymore and the last thing he wanted to do was to scare him.

Kevin suddenly leapt up having been thrusted out of his dream world causing all of his books to hit the floor with various thuds. He quickly crumpled to the ground to pick every one of them up. “Let me help you with that.”

Kuai descended upon Kevin, covering him in his huge shadow. He reached for Kevin’s math book just as Kevin jerked for it, causing their hands to touch. Instead of jerking away, Kevin froze, staring down at the floor. Kuai kept everything moving for Kevin’s sake and merely handed him the book. Trying to calm the boy’s nerves, Kuai said, “You know you didn’t need to bring all of your books from homeroom. Most teachers won’t start using them until tomorrow.”

Kevin was still frozen, staring at his hand. Kuai’s comment once again snapped him out of it and forced him to propel himself up. Clutching his books tightly, he said, “Th-thanks. Mr. Tao. It will never happen again!”

Kuai gave a hearty chuckle. “It is certainly not a crime to be over prepared.” He slowly rose in front of Kevin, filling the entire space between the nervous student and his desk. “Especially not in my class-- Kevin.”

Kevin finally looked up at Kuai and gave the sweetest most heartwarming smile. His heart slowed slightly to a steady gallop and he took a small sigh of relief. “Thank you, Mr. Tao.”

Kevin was no longer the jittery, spastic space cadet he had been moments ago. In that simple moment, Kuai could feel hooks of affection leap out from Kevin and snare his heart. Kuai wasn’t expecting any of this. Especially not on the first day. Kevin nodded, but didn’t move.

“Was there anything else?” Kuai asked.

Kevin slowly shook his head broadly from one side to the other, still wearing that enormous grin on his face. “Nothing else sir.” He slowly passed Kuai as he headed down the row. His head was still shaking slowly from side to side as he glided further away.

“That is one interesting kid,” Kuai thought to himself. 

“In fact---“ he thought, gripping his invisible pendant, “Let’s make Kevin a little more interesting.”

Kevin may have been tall for a seventh grader, but he was still nothing compared to Kuai. He decided to give him an edge on the other students. As Kevin slowly walked closer to the door,  Kuai imagined Kevin slowly growing to an even 6 feet with a swimmer's build. “Don’t want to give this kid too much too fast. He could crack.”

Kevin’s glide slowly halted and Kuai could hear Kevin’s breathing get louder. They almost sounded like faint moans. Kuai watched as the power of the pendant immediately took effect. Kevin’s body crept up higher in the air as all of his muscles slowly filled out. It was difficult to see under Kevin’s loose clothing, but Kuai could definitely make out  some new bulges in Kevin’s arms and thickening butt where none had been before.

After his steady ascent to six feet tall and thickened frame, the growth halted and Kevin continued his walk as if nothing had happened. When he reached the door, Kevin turned and gave a small wave to Kuai, still wearing that huge smile under his two, huge green eyes, “Bye, Mr. Tao.”

Kuai couldn’t help but give a small grin in return, noticing the slightly bigger bulges moving in Kevin’s arm. “See you later Kevin.”

Finally, Kuai was alone and he scrambled to check the various settings on the pendant. His arms flexed with huge bulges as he tugged on the object only he could see. “So, Kevin doesn’t know what just happened. He thinks he’s always been this way... Interesting”

This gave Kuai some ideas.
15111.title: After Class

choices: Kuai sees someone that looks a little familiar, and decides to change him
Kuai grows the mousy blonde boy into a beast.
151111.content:
Kuai looked at the clock on the wall. Two of the allotted six minutes between classes had elapsed, and his next class would start to trickle in shortly. He had to be quick. Sure, no one else would be able to see the pendant he was handling, but if someone saw him standing around fiddling his fingers in thin air, holding nothing, they might decide to put him in a strait jacket and lock him in a padded room for good measure.

Sitting down at his desk and turning his chair away from the door, he thought about the different settings Nick had described the day before. He knew the first two switches should probably stay on, for a while at least, as the pendant was too important for anyone else to know about it yet. He also wanted to have his changes stay unnoticed for a little bit longer, so it would probably be best to keep the 'unawareness' options turned on for now. That left the final switch, which Kuai guessed might turn out to be his favorite anyways. Nothing turned him on as much as thinking about someone's clothes stretch across their growing body, seeing each seam start to--

He heard footsteps enter his classroom, and he hurriedly tapped the fifth switch to the off position, then let go of the pendant, letting it drop back onto his chest. Spinning his chair around, Kuai saw a couple of students already sitting at their desks, talking to one another quietly. For a moment, his breathing had sped up and he could feel his heart pounding slightly, but he quickly realized that no one had noticed anything out of the ordinary.

As more students trickled in, the room became louder, and Kuai smiled inwardly. First period classes were always tough, as most of the kids were still a little tired from having to get up so early (a reason he had demanded - okay, begged - Principal Kaufman to put one of his honors classes first, since those students tended to participate more anyways). By second period, everyone was pretty much awake and ready to learn (well, most everyone; there always would be that one student who would doze off no matter what time of day it was).

This class was going to be a larger one than his first, being regular 7th-grade math, and Kuai knew that meant it had the potential to get a little out of hand if he didn't set the tone right here. A powerful monologue worked fine for honors students. For this class, though, he needed a prop: a baseball bat he had placed underneath his desk, a trick he learned from one of his college professors. He only would use it on the first day, and even then he never would mention it or do anything other than hold onto it a bit for all the class to see. The bat would then be put back under his desk for the rest of the semester, ready to be used again as a reminder if necessary, but, strangely enough, in the past two years Kuai had been a teacher, it so far had yet to need to make an encore. 

As the bell rang and the last few students filed in, Kuai pulled the bat out, holding it horizontally with both hands, and stood up, pacing in front of the class. When the students saw what Kuai was holding, and took in his intimidating height, their chatter died down almost immediately, and he could feel their eyes fixate on him with something between fascination and sheer terror. Kuai remained silent as he paced for a full minute, doing his best not to smile, as that would destroy the effect he was going for, though if one of the students looked very closely, they would see the corners of his lips turned upward just a bit.

Finally, Kuai spoke, his booming voice breaking the silence and filling the air. "Welcome class. My name is Mr. Tao, and I will be your math teacher this year. I take the subject of mathematics very seriously, and if you want to pass my class and be able to move up to eighth grade math, so will you."

Kuai paused for a moment and stopped pacing, his body now facing the class. Nobody moved a muscle, and 
Kuai could see some staring at him wide-eyed, mouths open in shock. Good, he thought. If I can capture them now, I'll have them for the entire year.

"Now some of you may be intimidated," he continued as he started to walk up and down the aisles, "by the concept of improper fractions, or the idea of solving for X. Well, I'm here to tell you, Don't be!" At the back of the classroom now, Kuai spun around quickly, causing one of the girls at the back of the class to jump a little in her seat. 

"Fractions, algebra, geometry," he resumed his slow march down another aisle of desks, "all the subjects we'll touch on this year, they all have at least one thing in common: they were devised and conquered by humans. And I've got news for you: everyone sitting in this classroom is human. And you can all conquer math, if you so choose."

He had them now, Kuai knew. Now to drive it home, so to speak. He stopped again, this time beside the desk of a particularly mousy blonde-haired boy, who nearly cowered in his shadow. "Now others of you might be intimidated by..." he motioned with his hands, indicating his own body, as he resumed his pacing, "....by this. By me. Don't worry, I'm not here to hurt you, and I don't get any pleasure from making people cry. I know it may be hard to believe, but I am actually a nice guy. Come to my class with your best effort, and I'll make sure that you will succeed. But if you come here with anything less, then prepare to be severely disappointed when report cards are handed out."

It was a performance worthy of an Oscar, Kuai thought. He only wished he could know right away if it connected with any of his students, though he thought he could see a few that genuinely understood. Only time would tell if he was right. But in the meantime, he had other, more... exciting, things to consider.
151111.title: Adjusting the Settings

choices: Kuai decides to grow multiple boys in his next class.
Kuai has a free period and wanders the campus.
1511111.content:
Roll call was next. After putting the bat away, Kuai made his way through the list of students, starting with 'Anderson, Deanna' and working down from there.  When he got to the last one, though, he felt an odd sense of deja vu.

"Wilkins, Austin."

"Here!" a bright, chipper voice answered. Kuai looked at where the voice was coming from, marked in his book, then nearly did a double take. The boy looked almost exactly like a younger, shorter version of Kurt Wilkins, one of Kuai's most talented 8th graders from last year's basketball team. He had a slender build and rather long, unkempt auburn hair that framed his face, deep hazel eyes, and fair, freckly skin. What Kuai really recognized, though, was the wide smile that had endeared him to Kurt as a coach and that interested him in Austin right away.

Kuai considered whether or not he should say anything, finally deciding he had to. "I'm guessing," he said to Austin, as he slowly stepped over to the marker board, "that you're related somehow to Kurt Wilkins."

Austin's warm eyes lit up, and he grinned widely. "Yup, he's my older brother! You coached him last year, right?"

Kuai nodded. "Glad to be able to work with one of the Wilkins boys once again." He wished he could talk a little more with Austin, but Kuai didn't want to put the spotlight on him to the detriment of the other students, so he moved on, starting the lesson. During the entire class, though, he eyed Austin, who seemed to be intently paying attention to Kuai's instruction and would always be one of the first hands raised to answer any question. Kurt had been one of the most outgoing boys Kuai had ever known, a true leader for the team, and it looked like he had passed on his energy and enthusiasm to his younger brother. Kuai was definitely intrigued.

As the bell rang, Kuai strode over to stand by the door. "Remember, pages 1-4, problems 1-24. Due tomorrow at the BEGINNING, not the end, of class." The students stood up and began to shuffle out, most of them not making eye contact with Kuai. Give 'em time, he thought.

Austin, though, walked right up to him and stuck out his hand. "It's great to meet you, Mr. Tao," the boy beamed as they shook. "Kurt went on and on about you, telling me that you're tough but fair, and that you really got on him last year to become the best basketball player he could be. I think that's a pretty awesome thing, in a coach or a teacher."

Grinning, Kuai cocked his head slightly. This boy was really something, he thought, possibly even more intriguing than Kurt. "Well, thank you, Austin," Kuai answered. "You seem to have a lot of enthusiasm for learning. Tell me, why aren't you in honors classes?"

"Oh, I am!" Austin replied. "It's just that I've always struggled with math. I don't know what it is, I just can't get my mind around it. But after a year of you teaching it to me, I know that I'll be calculating long division in my head, or solving complex equations in seconds flat, or whatever I need to do!"

If he didn't know Kurt, Kuai would've thought Austin was just trying to suck up to him. But the older boy had the same attitude, always positive and upbeat. It must run in the family, Kuai thought.

"See ya later, Mr. Tao!" Austin waved a little and then ran to catch up with his friends.

Kuai couldn't stop smiling, and he looked at the clock once more. There was a seventeen minute break now between second and third periods. Students would typically go to the cafeteria for a snack or sometimes to the library to study or to use the internet. Kuai knew he had to follow Austin and see where this bright young man was headed.

He stepped out of the classroom and looked down the hall to the direction Austin had gone towards, seeing him standing in a group of three or four other boys at the top of the stairs, leaning against the railing and chatting. Kuai kept his distance, far enough away not to be noticed, but close enough to eavesdrop on their conversation, and he kept his eyes moving, making sure it didn't look like he was watching them. Austin definitely was the most lively of the group, telling stories and jokes and moving his hands to illustrate them as he did. The other boys all seemed to listen to Austin, but he didn't dominate the conversation, listening to and encouraging the other boys. 

"He's definitely the spitting image of his brother," Kuai muttered under his breath. "Only…" There was one big difference that Kuai had noticed back in the classroom. Kurt Wilkins played center and was the tallest boy on the team, if not the whole school, standing 6'1" by the end of eighth grade and still growing. Austin, however, was on the smallish side for a seventh grader, several inches shorter than each of the other boys in the group he was in. 

His small stature  didn't seem to bother him any, Kuai noted. Maybe he just hadn't hit his growth spurt yet. "Perhaps I can help with that," Kuai said quietly as he fingered the pendant and a small smile crossed his face.

He focused on Austin, imagining his body even taller than Kurt's, with a slender build in the same proportions as the ones Austin had now. He also focused on having the transformation last a little longer this time than it had with Kevin. Might as well get the most out of it, he thought.

The boys stopped talking mid-sentence, and Austin's body started to sprout up. Kuai had momentarily forgotten that he had turned off the option for clothes to change, so he was slightly started when Austin's white uniform polo shirt became untucked, and his bulging arms started to push against the fabric of the sleeves. Once Kuai realized what was going on, though, his smile widened. The bottom of Austin's lean stomach began to show, and his thighs had started to fill in the loose leg-holes of the school shorts more fully. 

Austin was now taller than all of his friends, but he still continued to grow, his frame getting larger and larger. As his shoulders widened, the polo couldn't take the strain anymore, and the fabric started to rip down the middle of his shirt, with the seams near his shoulders and armpits also beginning to tear apart. The buckle of his belt snapped open, strained by his expanding hips, and the shorts started to inch down slightly on Austin's body, trying to find a narrower spot, before finally their snap popped open, revealing a pair of likewise-struggling boxer-briefs. Kuai hadn't paid any attention to the boy's shoes yet, but they, too, were getting their share of abuse, finally popping open and letting his toes, which had torn holes through his socks, have some air.

After what seemed to Kuai like an incredibly too-short time, the growing stopped, and the boys resumed their conversation, Austin towering over the others with his clothes in tatters. No one seemed to pay any extra attention to the six-foot-three seventh-grader in their midst who was now very much out of dress code. Autsin himself didn't even seem to care that his uniform had just gone to shreds. 

At one point in their conversation, his friend turned to him and remarked, "Hey, Austin, aren't those clothes a little tight?"

"Yeah," Austin replied, grinning as he casually looked down at his body. "I guess it's time for me and my mom to go shopping for some new uniforms."

Kuai chuckled to himself, excited by the results of Austin's changes, and bemused by the fact that no one treated the ripped clothes as anything rather unusual. "That could make things fairly interesting," Kuai thought, as the bell to end the break rang. Not that seeing a boy grow eighteen inches in less than a minute and having two six-foot-plus seventh graders in the school wasn't already interesting enough. But Kuai imagined that his day could only get more exciting from here.
1511111.title: Spitting Image ... Except for One Thing

choices: Patrick Evans, an average 12 y/o with ginger hair, pale skin & some freckles
Thomas Jordan, school wrestler with tight muscles, tan skin & bright blue eyes
15111111.content:
The passing period was almost over, so Kuai took quick, heavy steps back to his classroom. A sea of heads filled the hallway, bobbling beneath Kuai’s chest as each tried to clear out of the teacher’s way. He was certainly the tallest and the biggest person on the faculty, and the students—well, there was absolutely no contest. Kevin and Austin were no doubt the tallest seventh graders, but Kuai knew of one or two eighth graders that were even taller than them. Luckily, all the ones Kuai knew about were on the basketball team, and Kuai was their coach.

“The possibilities are endless!” Kuai excitedly thought to himself, making sure to keep a face of stone in front of the students.

A few seventh graders had already shown up for third period. By now, Kuai was getting a firm grip on his lesson and the introductions. He could just slip into auto pilot now, letting him concentrate on more interesting matters.

Everyone finished taking a seat. He began the lecture again, from the top with bat in hand. It was an even split of girls and guys, all of them with their unique sizes and shapes. Kuai decided to make things a little more interesting this period.

“---now when I call your name from the roll, I want you to come up to the front of the room, give us your name, tell us what you did over the summer break and what some of your interests are.”

The students didn’t dare groan at the suggestion, even though they had gone through a similar exercise for the past two periods.

“Chang, Allen,” Kuai called.

A short, Asian boy snapped to attention in the front row. His face was round and smooth, decorated with a pair of thinly framed oval glasses. He was clearly not an athlete, and took trepid steps as more and more eyes trained their sights on him. Allen’s chubby frame jiggled as he came to a halt in front of the center row. Kuai immediately saw how nervous he was. “Let’s give them something else to stare at, shall we,” he coyly thought to himself.

Allen began introducing himself with a quick and shaky voice to the class. What nobody other than Kuai noticed was all of Allen’s boyish fat slowly melting away. His polo hung looser and looser off his shoulders as all of his features thinned out. As his tummy continued to shrink, even his shorts began to slip from around his waist. Allen tried to pull it up, but the belt was no longer tight enough around his thinning waist. “I can fix that,” Kuai thought.

Kuai forced Allen’s tiny body to quickly shoot up several inches. Allen’s shoulders quickly broadened, his hips suddenly enlarged enough to catch the edges of his belt. His knees sprang out from beneath his shorts, exposing a lengthening field of smooth, olive skin. Allen was definitely no longer the shortest person in the class. With his introduction finally over, a much taller, thinner boy took his seat completely unaware of his former self. All he knew was that his shoes felt uncomfortably tight and that his shorts rode painfully high over his exposed legs.

Kuai was pleased with his work, but wanted to make sure they went unnoticed. He studied the reactions of the class intently—and nothing. Most were attentive, some were bored, but none were shouting, “Look, that kid grew six inches in under a minute!”

Kuai took a silent sigh of relief as he continued down the roll. Two girls and an uninteresting boy later, he reached, “Davis, Len.”

A slightly taller, trim Native American boy stood up from the back. He had bronze skin with long, straight black hair tied back in a loose pony tail. Some of the students snuck disapproving glares and snickers at Len, hoping Kuai hadn’t noticed. But they forgot that he was a teacher—he notices everything.

Len spoke with a smooth voice and a hint of an accent that Kuai couldn’t place. Despite the class obviously shunning him, he was rather calm as he spoke. “Good. Now watch this class,” Kuai thought, wielding the power of the pendant once more.

Len’s uniform fitted nicely around his thin features. That slowly began to change as Kuai went to work. Within moments of Len giving his name to the class, his muscles began to react. All of them slowly swelled from underneath his uniform, giving tight bulges were none had been before. The pocket sized, gold embroidered school emblem feebly stretched around Len’s chest as it slowly swelled from underneath. The two tight bulges pulled on the buttons of his polo as they swelled larger and larger. Even his knee high-khaki shorts couldn’t hide the thickening bulges erupting from his legs and butt.

Despite all of the different growing features on Len’s thickening body, Kuai was especially mesmerized by Len’s growing arms. The two, thin bronze poles quickly inflated with rippling bulges. Veins appeared around every bend, especially inside of the forearm. Each one pulsed just beneath the surface of his skin. His biceps forced his sleeves to tighten, and his sleeves forced even more veins to appear. All of this while both arms laid peacefully at his sides. It was a beautiful cycle in Kuai’s eyes.

Kuai also kept shooting glances at the class. He noticed the larger Len grew, the more eyes that burrowed into him. The snickers from before were long forgotten. Boys and girls alike were entranced by Len’s tight, gymnast build, and none of them remembered any different. Len didn’t notice how the students salivated at his muscular frame, any more than the students remembered him being an outcast just thirty seconds earlier.

“That’s probably enough,” Kuai thought to himself.

Just in time too. Len had finished with his introduction and begun to take his seat. Kuai immediately noticed how awkwardly Len was walking to his seat, constricted by his shrunken clothes. He also noticed how hard Len was trying to hide that fact, and that Len was the only one who cared. Kuai also couldn’t keep his eyes off of Len’s tight bubble butt or how each cheek swelled with every step he took. Len’s khaki’s could no longer hide just how large his muscles had gotten, and Kuai soaked in every moment of it.

As Len took his seat, Kuai called the next name, but could hear a distinct--- RIIIP--- as Len settled in his seat. Kuai’s commanding voice kept the attention of the class on him, but Kuai saw Len’s face turn beat red with one hand reaching around to feel his butt.

Who’s next?
15111111.title: Third Period Changes

choices: Tyler Phillips, a cute, but scrawny, energetic kid who can't keep still
Ryan Sanders, a jocky football type, now out shined by Patrick's huge body
151111111.content:
“Evans, Patrick!”

Kuai saw heard a sudden jerk directly in front of him. Patrick moved so quickly that he immediately lost his balance and tripped over a loose shoelace, propelling him face first along the polished tile. Kuai immediately shot his class a most sinister glare, prohibiting any laughter over Patrick’s spill. Still, even Kuai couldn’t stop the roar of stifled chuckling now sweeping the classroom.

“Are you alright,” Kuai tried to asked quietly to the boy sprawled out at his feet. Patrick rolled over, and saw the hulking figure standing directly above him. The harsh florescent lights accentuated his mighty silhouette and bathed Patrick in Kuai’s enormous shadow. With a huge gulp and a red face, Patrick jumped up in front of the class. His once pale face was now redder than a cherry, and he couldn't stop his stammering as he tried painfully to introduce himself.

Kuai saw the smirks and evil grins of the class. Many of them were enjoying Patrick’s thorough humiliation for no better reason than it wasn’t them. Kuai shot his eyes directly back to Patrick. His thin arms were locked behind him, and he even twirled one foot behind the other as he spoke. Patrick looked absolutely scared and painfully positioned, yet somehow he managed to keep his high, boyish voice talking.

For reasons unknown to Kuai, he had taken personal offense to the class' reaction to Patrick. His olive face reddened a bit and his eyes were now glued on the stammering redhead. “I’ll give them something to laugh about,” he huffed in his own mind.

Patrick had short, but scraggly ginger hair with hazel eyes and a light spackling of freckles all over his skin. He stood twisted in front of the class, barely capable of going on when all of the sudden, his body shot six inches into the air. His white polo immediately untucked from him pants, exposing a small portion of a slightly swollen stomach. Patrick’s pants rode up clear past his ankles and part of the way up his calves.

Somehow Patrick managed not to fall a second time when his body expanded. Instead, he reposition his feet to take a firmer stance, but his arms were still twisted behind his back. Half a second later, every muscle in his body quickly began to inflate. His polo suddenly tightened around the shoulder and helplessly tried to restrain his rapidly growing physique. Boulders erupted were only bone and fat had once been for his shoulders and arms. This forced Patrick to release them both and hang his arms on either side. Even though, in his mind, he merely chose to move his arms. (Instead of being forced to because they were too big to reach around his broadening backside.)

His chest quickly snapped both buttons of his shirt and even ripped the polo part of the way down his chest. This exposed hint a hint of the heaving slabs of meat barely restrained just under the thinning fabric.

His pants formed small rips in several places. Patrick’s calves widened and split the bottom seam of his pants. His high water socks were even forced to roll down and split in a few places. His quads and hamstrings stretched each pant leg as far as they would go. Another half inch around and they would have ripped clean off of him. Patrick’s butt wasn’t so lucky. With a quick rip, both glutes tore their way out of their small prison. His tight bubble butt was not going to be contained by such dainty fabrics.

Kuai finally realized what he had done and stopped Patrick’s growth immediately. “Damn! I forgot to make it where his clothes grew with him.” Kuai actually didn’t mind, he just feared for the boy he tried to protect.

Patrick finished with his introduction and immediately noticed that his clothes had burst. His face continued to blush as he scurried for his seat with awkward, heavy steps. Patrick's head was pointed straight at the floor, preventing him from noticing that he was about to plow directly into Kuai. Foretunely, Kuai had learned how to be quick on his feet and moved out of the young bodybuilder's way. Their two, respectively huge bodies couldn't fit in the same, tiny row of desks any With an unexpected--

THUD!

--and another loud--

RIIIP!

--Patrick, took his seat.

Patrick immediately crossed his enormous arms on his desk, splitting a sleeve in the process and put his head down on his desk, forcing his shirt to ride even higher up on his bare, but heavily muscled torso.

Kuai didn’t know how this was going to play out. Patrick was obviously still distraught, but what about the rest of the class. He surveyed the sea of faces with scrutiny. Kuai was pleased to find one distinct change from every person who had dared to chuckle at Patrick before: “Fear—

"Fear that Patrick heard them laugh at him and fear of what he might do to them if he knows who they are.”

The satisfied teacher even let out a tiny grin. “Much better,” he thought.

Kuai returned to his roll and continued the introductions. The next few students were girls and each nearly tripped over themselves because they couldn’t help but stare at Patrick’s (or Kuai’s) enormous body. Patrick may not have been as large as Kuai by a long shot, but he was certainly the most muscled kid in school. Something Kuai now knew he could change or keep with a single thought.

A few more boys came up on the list, but none of them interested Kuai. They were the typical private school rich kids, being too full of themselves already to deserve any assistance. Moving down closer to the end of the roll, though, Kuai finally came to a boy who looked like he could work with.
151111111.title: A Remarkable Redhead

choices: Wait! Tyler is distracted by something on his way out and stays to chat
Tyler leaves, and Kuai moves on to try to find another boy
1511111111.content:
"Phillips, Tyler!"

A small boy leaped out of his seat in the first row by the window and nearly sprinted to the front of the class, skidding to a stop in front of the board. His blue eyes sparkled with excitement and seemed to be constantly moving, never staying focused on one thing for very long. His school polo hung loosely off of his short, scrawny frame, and the cuffs of his khakis almost entirely covered his black shoes. Kuai guessed that even the extra-small sizes available for the middle school uniforms must have been a bit too big for this youngster. The boy brushed his wavy, unkempt, medium-length blonde hair out of his eyes before he began speaking, continuing to do so throughout his introduction. 

"Hi! I'm Tyler Jackson Phillips!" he exclaimed. "I play on the school soccer team, where I'm a midfielder and was a backup last year, but I hope to be a starter this year. I've been working on running long distances all summer, building up my endurance and stamina, plus since a bunch of guys from last year's team graduated, I should have a better chance." 

Tyler never stopped moving. Even as he "stood" in front of the class, he fidgeted uncontrollably. Kuai watched the energy shoot out of him in any way it could. "He's got potential," Kaui said, briefly fingering the invisible pendant.

Still talking, Tyler rattled off anything and everything that popped into his mind. "I love video games, and I have both a Sony Playstation 3 and a Nintendo Wii, though the Wii is technically my little sister's, but I play it more than she does. She likes her dolls and play sets, and I like my games. My favorites are Rock Band 3, Batman Arkham Asylum, and Super Smash Brothers Brawl." As he spoke, his eyes darted around the room, randomly focusing on various stimuli, including the clock, Kuai, some of the students, the items on Kuai's desk, and the ceiling tiles.

"I also like to travel, especially to amusement parks," Tyler continued. "This summer, my family and I went to Columbus, Ohio, to visit my grandparents and I got to go to both Cedar Point in Sandusky, which is north of Columbus, and Kings Island in Mason, which is right outside of Cincinnati, south of Columbus. They're two of the biggest amusement parks with the most and best roller coasters in the world, and I rode all of them. My favorites were Millenium Force at Cedar Point and The Beast at Kings Island, which I rode three times each."

As Tyler effortlessly raced to new topics, he became more and more excited, speaking at a faster pace and his slightly high-pitched voice getting a little louder with each new thing he mentioned. Kuai also noticed that he seemed to be almost jumping up and down now, his enthusiasm for all of the varied interests he described bubbling over in a display of exuberance that was just too cute. Amused, Kuai had to stifle a bubbling chuckle inside of him. At the same time, though, he saw a preppy-looking boy at the back of the class (Bradley Franklin the Third, Kuai coldly remembered from his haughty introduction) lean over to a girl in front of him, whispering, "What a little spaz!" 

The girl nodded, and Kuai's brow furrowed. Tyler might be a bit overeager, and he definitely had some distractibility issues, but the energy he brought to everything was contagious, and Kuai couldn't help but feel affection for the boy, and resentment towards anyone making fun of him. 

"Maybe this'll shut them up," Kuai thought to himself as he focused his mind on Tyler. He decided to only change him a little bit at a time, wanting to be careful not to make a hyper kid too big too fast, especially after what had happen with Patrick. In his mind, Kuai saw Tyler standing about six inches taller than he currently was, with a bit more meat on his bones; nothing too crazy for now, but something that would put him on par with the other boys in his class and help him fill out the uniform. 

Almost as soon as he visualized it, Tyler's body began to slowly grow upward. He continued talking uninterrupted, clearly oblivious to the fact that he was getting larger. His shoulders inched further apart as his entire frame expanded, the small shirt now stretched across his chest, not strained but definitely a tight fit. The tail of the shirt just barely became untucked, still hiding his slender stomach but not by much. Tyler's legs also got longer, his socks now visible below the pants-line, and the leather of the belt stretching a bit against his widening hips. 

As his growth finished, Tyler stopped talking, wincing in pain. He brought his hand up to his mouth and began to rub his lips. "Owww," he said, moaning softly.

"What's the matter, Tyler?" Kuai asked him, concerned that he had done something wrong; that somehow the pendant had ended up hurting him.

"Nothing," Tyler said, "it's just my braces." He flashed a bright smile at Kuai, revealing the metalworks inside. "I think the orthodontist tightened them too much yesterday. Don't worry, though, I'll be okay."

Kuai heard chuckling coming from a scattering of the other students, and shot a stern glare across the classroom before turning back to Tyler, feeling a mixture of concern and endearment for the boy. He had been too caught up in his smooth, flawless skin and bright sapphire eyes to notice the braces he wore, which must've stayed the same size along with the boy's clothes. "I'll have to be more careful about that kinda thing in the future," he thought. He breathed a sigh of relief that he had only decided to make Tyler's first growth a small one, and hoped he would be okay.

Tyler, though, had clearly gotten over it. He continued, still speeding up. "Anyways, I also make my own movies, writing out the screenplays, getting my family and friends to act in them, and then shooting them with my parent's camcorder, finally editing them on my MacBook and posting them to YouTube. I'm going to go film school for college at either NYU in New York or UCLA in California, becoming a movie director, and--"

Kuai realized that if he didn't step in and stop Tyler, the kid would probably keep talking for the rest of the period, which by now only had about twenty minutes left anyways. He held out his hand and said, with as gentle a voice as possible, "That's enough for now, Tyler." Tyler looked at him, a slight sense of disappointment in his large eyes that made Kuai feel terrible for stopping him. Hating that feeling, Kuai grinned and said, "Don't worry, I'm sure we'll find out everything else about you during the rest of the year."

A smile returned to Tyler's face, and he nodded. He ran back to his desk, nearly hitting another student's desk with his bigger-than-normal feet, plopping back into the chair. Kuai shook his head in amusement. "That kid is going to be a whole lot of fun to grow," he thought.

Only two other boys were after Tyler in the roll list, both bulky football players whom Kuai didn't feel like making any bigger. Once the entire class had spoken, Kuai used the remaining time to go over the basic subjects that were going to be covered in the first lesson. As he wrote a stream of numbers and symbols on the board, explaining what they signified, Kuai would always turn and look back at the class, making sure everyone comprehended what he was saying. He also watched the three boys he had grown, interested in how they handled their larger bodies. 

Kuai especially kept an eye on Tyler, who swung his legs back and forth underneath his desk, lightly tapping his pencil against his notebook subconsciously. He seemed to be making an intense effort to look up to the front of the classroom and stay focused, though he would also occasionally look out the window to his left, perhaps at a car pulling out of the parking lot, a fly buzzing through the classroom, or at the titles of books on the bookshelf nearby. Whenever Kuai noticed Tyler drift off, he would try to get his attention, saying a particular phrase extra loud, stomping his foot as he turned, or tapping against the board loudly with the marker. Each time, Tyler would quickly face forward, looking into Kuai's eyes with a sheepish grin that indicated he knew he had been caught. His grin, more than anything, with the wired teeth and slightly swollen lips, captured Kuai's heart the most. "He is one cute kid," he thought when he turned back to the board. "I just need to change the settings back to their defaults, so his braces don't explode in his mouth." Taking the pendant in hand, trying to make it look as casual as possible, he quickly turned on the screen, switching the clothing option back on. "There. Now to have some--"

RIIIINNNNGGGG

Before he could finish that thought, the class was over. A little disappointed, Kuai nevertheless made sure to hide that fact from his face as he turned back to remind the class of their homework assignment. The boys and girls stood up to leave, Tyler dawdling a bit towards the back of the group. Kuai wished he could spend more time with the boy, but it looked like he would have to wait.
1511111111.title: Hyper Boy Growing

choices: 4th period next, with lunch in the middle of it
Commotion in the halls - one of the boys Kuai grew is in a fight!
15111111111.content:
Kuai watched from the door as Tyler hurried down the aisle to leave. He was just about to turn towards the door when he stopped, his mouth hanging open a little. Pointing, he looked up at Kuai, excitement once again bubbling up in his voice. "Whoa! Is that from UCLA, Mr. Tao?"

Kuai knew immediately what Tyler was referring to: a framed basketball jersey leaning against the wall beside his desk, waiting to be hung on the wall. "Yes, indeed, Tyler," Kuai's face went from stone-faced teacher mode to a more casual, friendly demeanor as he walked over to the desk. "That is a Bruins jersey."

"Wow, whose is it? Is it Abdul-Jabbar's? Walton's? Miller's?"

Kuai shook his head, smiling in a mixture of pride and embarrassment. "No, Tyler. That's, um, actually... my jersey."

Tyler practically jumped through the ceiling. "Holy crap! You played for the Bruins?" Kuai nodded, beginning to say something, but Tyler interrupted. "Wait! I think I remember you… yeah! You played power forward for a couple of seasons about six or seven years ago, right? I was just starting to watch basketball then, but I remember seeing a really tall Asian guy play." Tyler beamed with pride and excitement. "You know, I think I confused you with Yao Ming a few times." 

A moment later, Tyler’s grin sagged, immediately replaced by a worried look. "Uh, what I… I didn't mean…" He started running his hands through his hair, a nervous sweat forming on his forehead. "Ah, geez. You’re not him. You’re you! I'm sorry!"

Kuai couldn't help but laugh out loud at Tyler's cute, boyish nervousness. "Don't worry, Tyler," he said. "You wouldn't be the first. I guess most people don't think that there are very many Chinese men this tall." He felt an urge to pat Tyler on the shoulder, but fought it, hesitant to initiate any kind of physical contact. Instead, he leaned against his desk, sitting on his hands. "But, you know, Yao is a bit older than me, and almost a foot taller. I'd like to think I got him beat in the looks department, though." 

"Yeah, that's definitely true," Tyler's face washed over with a wave of relief. "Well, anyways, I'm a huge Bruins fan. I told you that's where I want to go to college, right? For film school!"

Kuai nodded. "Or NYU."

Tyler sighed and rolled his eyes. "Yeah… that's where my mom wants me to go.  She doesn't think I should be going to school clear across the country."

"Well," Kuai stood back up, "you're just now starting seventh grade. It's not bad to be planning for college this early, but you still have plenty of time to choose. Who knows," he added with the hint of a wink, "maybe, by then, you'll be able to convince her. And if you need an alumnus recommendation, be sure to let me know."

Tyler's eyes lit up, and Kuai could tell that he understood him. "Yeah… Yeah! I sure will! Thanks, Mr. Tao!" He grinned again and turned towards the door, bouncing with every step. Kuai watched contently, enjoying the view and thinking about all the different possibilities the pendant gave him with this boy. 

As Tyler reached the door, though, he stopped. After a second's pause, he slowly turned back around, looking up into Kuai's eyes with an honest, hopeful expression. "Mr. Tao? Can I tell you something?"

Kuai slowly nodded, unsure of what Tyler was going to say, but preparing himself for anything.

"I guess you noticed in class today that I can be a little hyper or distracted sometimes."

Holding back a chuckle, Kuai looked straight at Tyler's eyes. "Yes, I did, Tyler. It'd be kind of hard to miss."

The corner of Tyler's lips turned upward slightly, and his cheeks reddened. "Yeah, well… I haven't told this to any of my other teachers today yet, but… well, for some reason, I feel I can trust you already. Last week, my mom took me to a doctor-- not my normal doctor, but a psychiatrist. He asked a whole bunch of questions and ran some tests, and, at the end, he told her I have ADHD." 

Kuai smiled as gently as possible. "I figured as much."

"Yeah, I guess it is kinda obvious, isn't it?" Tyler chuckled, his hands brushing away another bit of hair that had fallen into his eyes.

"Are you on any medication?"

Tyler shook his head. "Nope. Not yet anyways. The doctor said that he wants me to learn about ADHD first and see if I can manage it on my own before he prescribes anything."

Kuai smiled with assurance, this time overcoming his worry and taking the boy’s shoulder with a strong teacherly grip. “I’m sure you will be fine Tyler. And let me know if there is any way I can help.”

“Oh, you bet Mr. Tao!" Tyler’s bright face lit up again, flashing Kuai with his reflective braces. "I knew you would back me up! Thanks! This year's already shaping up to be a big success!”

"Yes, it is," Kuai said, eyeing Tyler's slightly bigger but still skinny frame once more. "In fact," he said, this time just to himself, "let's make it the biggest yet." Quickly thinking about what to do, he started imagining Tyler growing yet again, slowly but steadily, inch by inch until he became eye level with Kuai. Sure, it would undoubtedly make him the biggest seventh grader on earth, but if the pendant worked the way it was supposed to, no one would freak out or think that Tyler had ever been any different. In addition, he focused on filling out Tyler's skinny frame with a layer of tightly defined muscles, making sure not to go too extreme, but giving him a true athlete's body.

Before he had even finalized his thoughts, Kuai saw that the pendant was already at work. Tyler was looking away from Kuai, having seen something out the window that had caught his interest, so he didn't notice the delighted expression on Kuai's face when he started sprouting up. The growth was much more noticeable than before, even though this time his clothes expanded with him. Within a few seconds, he was eye level with Kuai's chest and still getting bigger. The muscles in his torso and arms pushed outwards, filling in the school uniform, which was able to stretch to cover them adequately enough. His elongating thigh and leg muscles swelled, the fabric of his pants keeping up with their expanded form, if only barely.

Tyler was now as big as any of the other students at the school, but he didn't stop there. He continued to get taller, the pendant and its invisible nanites still driven by Kuai's thoughts. Tyler was coming close to be able to look Kuai in the eye, and his body now looked like one that he'd worked hours in the gym to create. The fabric of his shirt, still tight from not growing with him during his introduction, did little to hide the peaks and valleys of his pecs, and the rippling biceps in his forearms. Though Kuai himself had a toned body, he realized that Tyler must now be even more muscular than he was! His shoes, having grown in proportion with the rest of Tyler, also looked to be larger than Kuai's, probably now size twenty or more. Kuai's thoughts for a moment turned to what those huge feet inside must now look like. 

As Tyler reached Kuai's height, his growth slowed to a stop, and Kuai could've sworn he heard a slight satisfied moaning sound coming from Tyler's mouth, though he figured he must've imagined it. The boy was now an amazing specimen, by far the tallest person in school, student or otherwise (other than Kuai of course). The youthful face on top of the huge, statuesque body drove Kuai wild inside, and he had to shift his legs to hide his arousal. Of all the changes he had made using the pendant so far, Tyler's were definitely the most impressive.

The boy now seemed to be looking back at Kuai, that adorable grin still on his face. Kuai guessed that, with Tyler now believing himself to have been exceptionally tall all his life, he must enjoy being able to finally talk with someone he didn't have to turn his head down to look in the eye.  Much as he enjoyed admiring Tyler and getting to know him, Kuai realized that both of them needed to move on. His fourth period students had started walking in, and the clock showed only two minutes left before the bell rang. "Tyler," Kuai said firmly but softly, "you should get going. I don't want you to be late for your next class."

Snapping back to reality, Tyler quickly looked at the clock on the wall. "Oh crap!" he shouted, his voice still the same pitch as before but noticeably more powerful. "Thanks, Mr. Tao! I'll see ya tomorrow!" He quickly turned around and bolted out the door. His large feet slammed against the floor, causing e walls to shake slightly. His movement still contained all the intensity and vigor of the 4' 10" boy he had first entered the classroom as. It seemed as if the growth had done nothing to take away his energy or his restlessness; indeed, it only served to magnify it! Kuai couldn't wait to see the giant hyperactive boy tomorrow, but he knew that he still had more school to get through today.
15111111111.title: Exploding With Both Energy And Growth

He decides to eaves drop. This could be interesting.
151111111112.content:
BANG!

A metal ring shot into Kuai’s classroom. “That wasn’t the bell!” Kuai thought.

All of his students, both inside the classroom and out, clogged the doorway and hall, eager to find out what was going on. Kuai approached, speaking with a forceful tone. “Excuse me!”

The tiny seventh graders, dwarfed by Kuai’s enormous body, quickly tried to scatter out of his way. A few even bumped into him, bouncing off his hardened body. However, there were just too many of them, and it took a whole minute before Kuai was able to shove his mighty frame into the hallway.

Kuai found the source of the bang: about twenty feet away, a huge section of lockers had crumpled under some powerful force. Tyler stood with his back to those lockers, surrounded by about four other boys, two from Kuai’s last class. “Teach you to run into me like that again!”

“I’m sorry! I didn’t see you! You’re just so---“ He stopped himself. “I really didn’t mean to!” Tyler pleaded.

“Yeah,” one of the boys snarled, “And I didn’t MEAN to do this either!” He wound his fist back and launched it into Tyler’s rippling stomach. That alone wouldn’t have been enough to hurt Tyler, but another boy punching Tyler in the gut at the same time, while the third held his foot out to trip him. It was enough to send the overactive titan back into the lockers with another loud, reverberating---

BANG!

Tyler’s body cradled deeper inside the increasingly disfigured lockers. A look of anguish wiped across his face. “What are you doing Tyler? Fight back!?” Kuai anxiously thought to himself as he fought his way through the sea of students watching the fight.

Tyler trembled with fear. “Look. I promise. It will never happen again. I just got distracted! I was walking. Didn’t see. Then, I---“ he huffed.

“You smashed that body of yours right into me, making me drop my stuff!” the leader interrupted. “And there is no excuse for that-- Freak!”

“Yeah. Freak!”

“FREAK!”

Another group of boys near the fight chimed into this malicious chorus. Tyler looked feverish and defeated. Everyone seemed sided against him. What was he going to do? Kuai furiously thought, “I am going to end this!”

Kuai was still trapped about ten feet away, but this fight was over, as far as Kuai was concerned. Kuai immediately took hold of the pendant, focusing on Tyler’s attackers. The leader wound back his thick arm up for another punch, but as it sailed through the air, all of his muscle quickly melted away. By the time his fist made contact with Tyler’s stomach, this boy was no bigger than Tyler once had been.

His hand crumpled like paper against Tyler’s steel abdomen. “Ow! That hurt, Freak!”

Another boy tried to avenge their former leader, but Kuai made the same changes to him. He yelped in pain and grabbed his reddened hand.

Within seconds, all four boys were transformed. Before, they ranked among the biggest and the strongest seventh graders in the whole school. But now, each was smaller and weaker than Tyler had been, helpless and unable to dent Tyler’s huge muscles.

“Come on guys,” the leader called out with a whiny, high pitched voice. “We’re done with this Freak!”

The leader coddled his hand as all four of them disappeared up the hallway. Kuai thought about running after them and punishing them with anything the school could throw at them, but he decided he had done enough. Those four boys could never physically hurt Tyler again.

The tardy bell rang and the sea of students quickly cleared. The boys that had chanted “Freak” earlier lost their nerve as the crowd thinned and scattered away from the crumpled titan. Kuai slowly approached Tyler. The boy’s head hung low, his huge body cradled in the deformed locker that his back had pulverized twice now. Kuai even heard small sobs escape the boy’s lips.

“Tyler—“ Kuai said quietly with sweetness and concern.

“They hate me,” Tyler sobbed, rubbing one eye with a huge, clinched fist. “They all do.”

“No, they don’t,” Kuai lied.

Tyler nodded, keeping his eyes closed. “They call me ‘Freak’. They always have. For as long as I can remember, people have always looked at me and thought I was different. I know I’m big… but I’m still a kid! I still like to play. I still like to laugh and have fun.”

His sobs worsened. “And now with this ADD thing, they are just going to have more of a reason to---to—“ Tyler couldn’t contain it anymore. He wailed.

Tyler flung his body upon Kuai and wrapped him in the biggest hug he could. Tyler’s tears quickly soaked Kuai’s shoulder, his huge chest muffling Tyler’s sobs.

Kuai was stunned for a moment, his arms just hanging at his side. “School rules be damned,” he decided. This boy was in pain, and Kuai was probably the only person in the world that could understand the EXACT pain this boy was going through. Kuai slowly closed his arms around Tyler’s huge torso. He was even more heavily muscled than Kuai had originally thought. “It’s going to be alright Tyler. I’ve got you. I promise, it’s going to be alright.”

Tyler pulled his body even closer to Kuai, trying to let his words comfort him. After a minute of bawling tears in the hall, Tyler finally quieted back into sobs. He lifted his head up, exposing his moist, reddened face. “Even mom doesn’t get it. I know she tries. But she’s nothing like me. She doesn’t know what it’s like to be— so—“ The final word hurt Tyler’s lips to say it. “—different.”

Kuai knew exactly what Tyler meant. His size hadn’t always been a blessing for him either. Kuai tried to speak, but couldn’t. His eyes had locked into Tyler’s. But somehow, Tyler reacted. Even though his cute, young face was still twisted with pain, a slight smile appeared. Tyler looked into his eyes, but it felt like he was looking into Kuai’s soul.

“You— are like me.”

With these simple words, Tyler summed up everything Kuai could have said to console him. Tyler’s blunt nature and knack for honesty struck Kuai in a most personal way. This look on Tyler’s face reminded him of Kevin just a few hours go. Kuai’s heart fluttered as he thought of the two boys.

All of the pain flowing through Tyler slowly subdued, overcome by his revelation. “If you are like me, that means you are the only person in the world that understands me,” Tyler’s innocent logic began. “And if you understand me, that means you can help me.”

Kuai slowly nodded, his eyes widening at Tyler’s sudden wisdom. But the boy wasn’t finished. Though his flushed face still dripped with tears, he smiled, completing his thought. “—that means I can help you too.”

Kuai was speechless. Why was Tyler having this effect on him? Before Kuai could consider the thought further, Tyler actually giggled. “Like a teacher would ever need my help!”

If only Tyler knew. They released from their embrace and slowly stood back up. Tyler and Kuai both towered above the lockers and the empty hallway. Tyler slowly collected the books at his feet, hugged them close to his meaty chest and asked, “Is it alright if I come by after school?”

Kuai nodded. “Sure, Tyler. I’ll be in my room.”

Tyler lit back up into his former self. His reddened face beamed with excitement. “Now, you had better get to class, Tyler. We are both running late.”

“Oh gosh! What time is it!?” Tyler snapped around his empty wrist, looking for a watch that did not exist. “Oh, duh! I’m late!”

Tyler turned and bounced down the hallway. But before he got too far, Kuai called out. “And Tyler--!”

Tyler immediately skidded to a halt, poking his head from around the corner. “Try not to bump into anyone else today,” Kuai grinned.

Tyler tightly closed his eyes and flashed a full set of braces at Kuai. “Will do Mr. Tao! See you after school!”

Tyler whipped back around the corner, an irregular beat of thudding feet fading down the hall. Kuai turned and headed back for his classroom. He actually found himself slightly saddened by the fact that Tyler was gone. “He is really some kid.”

As Kuai entered his room, he saw a group of kids just inside the door gossiping about the fight. He wanted to hear what they were saying. "But what about class?" Kuai wondered, "Shouldn't I go ahead and get started?"
151111111112.title: Unexpected

A depressed emo kid with long, flat hair covering his eyes.
1511111111122.content:
All of his students were standing around the room in clusters, excitedly discussing all that had gone on that day. No one noticed their teacher entering. Kuai heard a group near the door gossiping about the fight, and he casually retreated into the hall unseen, interested in what they had to say. Maybe this could give him a better insight into Tyler, along with everyone else’s perception of this reality.

“—I still can’t believe those guys tried to pick on that kid!” one girl shrieked.

“Kid!? You mean Freak!” a tough tenor voice said. “Guys our age aren’t supposed to be that big!”

“Maybe there’s something wrong with him,” the first girl defended. “You know, a medical thing or something.”

“Or maybe steroids!” a surprisingly deep-voiced guy suggested.

“You don’t think!?” a second girl gasped.

“Oh yeah, I saw him taking some pills last year! He said it was for his allergies. But I knew what they were! One of his soccer teammates said he took them all the time right before a game,” the second guy smugly concluded.

“Oh, a soccer player!” the first girl swooned.

“You didn’t know?!” the first guy snapped sharply. “But-- have you seen him play!? I hear he’s always missing the ball or kicking it clear off the field.”

“I even heard he busted a ball once. Kicked it and the ball— exploded,” the second guy boomed, his voice sounding like a hollow drum. “They almost had to forfeit the game.”

Both girls swooned. The first guy, got a little heated. “Not only is he a Freak, but a screw-up!”

The first girl snapped out of it and spoke again. Kuai winced the sound of her voice, like nails on a chalkboard. “But why would those four little goons try to beat him up? They barely come up to his waist! They must have known they didn’t stand a chance. I’m surprised he let them get as far as they got.”

“It’s because he’s a pushover!” the first guy exclaimed, “And everyone knows it. You saw how he just stood there. That kid may be big, but he knows he’s a Freak. That’s why he doesn’t fight back! And why bother? Once a Freak, always a Freak!”

“Yeah. Freak,” the second guy repeated mindlessly.

Kuai broke out into a sweat, his blood boiling. He certainly found out everything he could handle for now. With one large step, he filled the entire doorway, the top of his head obscured by the molding. Kuai glared at his class, especially the group of four near the door. Based on their appearances, Kuai guessed the tall blonde girl had the shrilling voice and the shorter girl with honey brown hair was the other. As for the boys, the ringleader who seemed to have it out for Tyler was a shrimp of a child with greasy hair and thin lips. The other boy stood taller than the rest, extra large with a perpetual blank look on his face. Clearly the first boy was this one’s master, following him like a dog on an invisible leash.

They got one look at Kuai and darted for their seats. The rest of the class heard their hurried footsteps and followed suit. Kuai could barely think straight, furious after what he had just heard. He knew that kids could be cruel, just like adults, but it was always tough being reminded of their senseless maliciousness. The next half-hour was a blur up until lunch. The class left quickly, leaving all of their stuff behind. It took every ounce of strength within Kuai’s enormous body to close the door softly. His face flushed with a bright red. His eyes burned with an intense fire. And a bellowing scream burst out of chest as he drove his tightly clinched fist into a wall.

THUD!

Threads in Kuai’s sleeve snapped as his bicep fought angrily against it. The drywall rattled against Kuai’s power. His hand rested just inside the wall. Kuai did not notice nor care. His mind was consumed with what he had heard. It took a full five minutes in silence before he got his lunch out from behind his desk. Kuai’s thoughts continued to swirl around and around the cruel words those kids had said about Tyler. “If just a few kids feel that way, what about the rest of them?!”

He furiously ate his way through a ham sandwich and sucked a small container of juice dry. Kuai didn’t stop to breathe. His mind leapt to a few of the other kids he had changed. He had hoped, despite the pleasure he got out of changing each person, that he had benefited them in some small way; that their changes would help them cope and fit in. “But if that’s how they treat Tyler… I don’t know.”

Kuai dwelled on these thoughts through the rest of fourth period after the students returned from lunch, running through them in his mind while he droned on with the lesson.
