“It’s a cat!” Kuai said, while looking up at the tree. He spotted a small, gray-haired kitten, who was standing on one of the branches, just over twenty feet above the ground.

Makani positioned himself just below the spot where the cat was standing and he tried to reach out with his long, muscular arms, when he realized that even he was out of reach. Then, he tried standing on his toes, but the branch was still too high.

“Rats! The branch is still too high for me! I can’t reach it!” Makani grumbled, as he even tried leaping in the air but barely missing the branch.

Kuai then looked down at the pendant, which hung from his neck, as he looked up at the giant boy. He realized that this was the perfect opportunity to give Makani his big growth spurt.

“Hey, Makani!”

“Uhmm… Yes?” the boy responded, as he turned to face his teacher, who was smiling back at him while holding his pendant in his hand.

“Time for another growth spurt, my friend!”

“Oh! Kuai! You’re gonna use the pendant to make me gr--… WHOA!” the giant boy gasped as he was overcome by an intense prickling sensation in his arms and his legs.

As Makani looked down, he could see everything around him shrink very slowly. The trees, the buildings, the people in the distance, the cars in the parking lot… Everything seemed to be shrinking. As the boy looked sideways, the large oak tree seemed to be shrinking as well, as the branch that the kitten was standing on slowly appeared to be coming closer and closer to his line of sight.

Finally, the odd tingling sensation stopped. When Makani looked straight ahead, he was looking down at the top of the oak tree. He was able to bend down and extend his mighty arm, and allow the kitten to jump from the branch onto his huge hand.

“Here kitty kitty!” Makani said quietly, as he squatted down and set the poor, scared kitten on the ground. That’s when he looked up and spotted Kuai, who now looked much smaller than before.

“Kuai? Is that you?”

When Makani looked down, he saw a short man standing before him. The man only came up to his knees!

“Well, Makani…. How do you feel?” Kuai asked the giant boy.

“How… Why… How did you get so small?” Makani asked the little man standing before him.

“I didn’t shrink or change size at all! You, my friend, have grown to the impressive height of thirty feet!” his teacher responded.

“Whooaaa!” Makani said, as he turned both ways as he looked around. Then it dawned on him. Everything seemed smaller to him.

Several other people walked up to Makani, curious to meet the young, giant boy.

When Makani looked down and realized that all the other people were also small compared to him, he realized that what Kuai had said earlier was indeed true: Makani had grown to enormous proportions!

“Oh man… I was big before but now I’m REALLY big!”

Just then Jonathan came walking along with his son Jason in tow. These were the father-and-son pair whom Kuai and Makani had met at the swimming pool, an hour earlier. Jason immediately came running towards Makani and stopped right in front of the giant boy.

“Whoa, Makani! You look big!” the boy chuckled. Concerned that the boy noticed a change in height, Kuai checked the settings and made sure that the fourth switch was still on, which it was. He guessed to himself that just being around a thirty-foot-tall twelve-year-old was big enough for anyone to notice, no matter what the nanites did.

“You know what you could do?” Jonathan suggested to Kuai. “You should take Makani to the fairgrounds tomorrow! People will line up to have their pictures taken with Makani! Especially since he’s so big!”

Kuai pondered the idea for a moment. He liked the idea a lot!
15111111111221111122121111.title: Makani grows even more in the park

choices: Time to grow for the fair
Getting ready to go to the fair
151111111112211111221211111.content:
Makani started walking towards the house, grinning as he looked down and saw the tiny people and cars riding and walking on the street below him. Of course, everyone stopped in order to look up to the giant boy! Makani just kept on walking until he heard his teacher calling out to him.

“Makani! Stop! I can’t keep up with you!” Kuai said, as he came running after the towering boy. “I can’t keep up with your stride, big guy!”

Kuai finally caught up to him and stood before the tall Hawaiian, panting from the short sprint.

“Want me to carry you?” Makani laughed, as he extended his huge hand as he squatted down.

Kuai then stepped on to Makani’s hand as Makani lifted him up to eye level. Makani then started walking, while holding out his hand.

“What an incredible view from up here!” Kuai grinned.

Makani made it to the house in just three minutes, walking at an amazing speed with his long, powerful legs. Once they arrived, Kuai directed the boy to step over the six-foot fence and to walk over to the back yard behind the house. There, Makani squatted down and allowed Kuai to get back on the ground, when Kuai took a few steps back and took hold of the pendant.

“I’m going to shrink you down so you can get into the house, big guy!”

Just as he said, the giant Hawaiian boy suddenly began to dwindle down in size! Everything around him began to increase as Makani’s arms, legs and torso went through a rapid shrinkage, all in proportion. Luckily, his shoes, shorts and t-shirt also dwindled along with the rest of his body. It was an incredible sight for Kuai to see the giant boy shrink before his eyes, until he was finally reduced to standing 6 feet tall again.

“Wow! Even shrinking feels amazing!” Makani grinned, as he continued to dwindle until Kuai reduced him down to his original height of 5 foot 3 inches.

“Now, this was how tall you were before I started making you grow, a few days ago!” Kuai pointed out. “Let’s go inside so I can experiment some more before we go to the fair tomorrow!”

Makani walked into the living room and stood in the center of the room while Kuai sat down on the couch before him.

“Let’s see here…” Kuai grinned, as he looked over the pendant and the switches. “I can grow all of you or just part of you!”

“Really? Just a part of me? That’s awesome!” Makani giggled. “Try it out on me!”

Kuai realized how much Makani just loved the sensation of feeling his body grow and shrink so he was more than happy to volunteer himself as his test subject. Kuai looked up at the boy and focused on just one part of the boy’s body.

Suddenly, Makani felt a tingling in his hands, both of them! Then, as he raised up his arms, he realized that his palms, and his fingers were growing! His thumbs and all his other fingers were growing longer and thicker, while his hands were almost twice as big as before!

“Wow! My hands! You grew my hands!” Makani gasped, as he admired his huge hands, which were the size of baseball gloves now.

“Take off your sandals, dude!” Kuai ordered, as he looked down at the boy’s feet.

Makani kicked the sandals off, as moved them aside. Almost immediately, he was overcome by a tingling sensation in his feet, and as he looked down, he noted his feet and all his toes growing longer and wider at the same time. His feet grew to the point where they were twice as long as before, and twice as wide. They were as big as fins!

“Ack! I got big feet!” Makani laughed, as he lifted up his huge feet.

“You know, I can also grow your muscles!” Kuai laughed, as he concentrated on the boy’s arms.

Makani let out a loud gasp as his chest began to expand while his biceps in his arms began to inflate. Both biceps began to swell as they inflated like balloons, growing to the size of melons as they felt hard as rocks. In the meantime, Makani’s flat chest suddenly came to life as his pecs pushed outwards and sideways, filling outward and making the boy look like a junior bodybuilder!

“This… This is amazing! You can do so much with that pendant! I love this!” Makani said, as he flexed both arms.

“I knew you’d like this!” Kuai grinned, as he looked over the muscular boy.

Next, Makani felt his torso grow bigger in every direction! His entire midsection was growing taller and wider! His chest and his stomach were just getting bigger and bigger, making the boy stand taller and wider, thanks to the pendant!

“Whoa!”

“Don’t worry! I’ll put you back in proportion and then I’ll make you grow bigger before we go to the fairgrounds! How tall do you want to be?” Kuai asked the boy.

“Umm… Twelve feet tall?”

“Why that tall?”

“Then I’m twice as tall as all the grownups!” Makani answered.

“Okay, champ. You got it!” Kuai grinned, as he concentrated on Makani shrinking back to normal sized before he made him grow back to eight feel tall, in proportion. “How is eight feet? Is that tall enough for you, for tonight?”

“Yeah!”

Kuai just looked up at the big, smiling boy. He was becoming a growth-junkie, but Kuai didn’t mind. He would make Makani grow any day.
151111111112211111221211111.title: More shrinking and growing before the fair

choices: They all three pile into Kuai's car, making record time to the fair.
Sean gets called to work at the last minute. Kuai and Makani go by themselves
1511111111122111112212111112.content:
After saying good night to Makani and making sure the boy went to bed, Kuai headed to his own room, fairly sleepy as well. It only took a few minutes after he climbed into bed with Sean before he conked out for the night. His rest was a peaceful one, not waking up at all until the next morning.

Sunlight had just started to stream in through the window blinds, and Kuai had barely opened his eyes when he heard the sound of a door fly open and two large feet running through the hall, then a fist pounding on their door. "Kuai! Sean!" Makani's voice filled the entire upstairs of their house. "C'mon, wake up! Let's get goin' to the fair!"

Groaning, Kuai gently pulled his arm off of his boyfriend and rolled over, looking at the small alarm clock on the nightstand. Red digits reading 7:15 blinked back at him.

"Ergggg," Sean mumbled into his pillow. "Doesn't that kid know anything about sleeping in on Sundays?"

Kuai chuckled. "Give him a break. He's never gotten a chance to go to a fair. I guess they don't have those in Hawaii... at least, anything like The Big E." The Eastern States Exposition, or The Big E as it was more commonly called, had just started, still in its first weekend of the year. The large event basically counted as the state fair for their area of the country, where all six New England states came together to showcase agriculture and livestock, as well as to host various shows and entertainment, topped off with a midway full of dozens of rides and games. Though they would have to drive a couple of hours over to Springfield on the other side of Massachusetts, Kuai knew that the trip would be worth it, giving his big Hawaiian boy a day that he wouldn't soon forget.

He threw his feet over the side of the bed and slowly walked over to the door, opening it partway. Makani's face beamed down at him from the other side, wide awake, full of excitement. The boy had already gotten dressed in a black sleeveless shirt, khaki cargo shorts, and black sneakers, all ready to go.

"Makani," Kuai rubbed the sleep out of his eyes, "relax. We're gonna have plenty of time to get there."

"But," the boy protested, "the website says the gates open at eight! That's only 45 minutes from now, and it'll take us twice as long as that to get there! And it's the first weekend of the fair too, so it's gonna be crowded like heck!"

Grinning, Kuai looked past the eight-foot-tall boy and noticed that the light in the upstairs office was still on, and he could make out the faint glow of the computer monitor from inside. He realized that Makani had probably been up for a while already, finding out as much about the fair as he could. "Well, you're technically right about the time for the gates," the teacher finally nodded, "but the buildings, rides, and exhibits don't open until ten o'clock or later. We can have a nice breakfast here, climb into the car a little before eight, and pull up to the fairgrounds just as everything starts to open. Don't worry; we'll have plenty of time to see anything you want to see."

"Okay..." the boy sighed but reluctantly agreed, turning around heading back to the office to get on the computer again.

Kuai turned around, seeing Sean, who had sat up in bed, stretch and yawn. "Gee," Sean said after a second, "I wonder where that kid gets all that excess energy. You'd think he'd need to conserve it all in order to fuel that big body of his."

"Yeah, well I guess the pen--" Kuai stopped himself mid-word, realizing that in the few weeks or so since he had received the pendant in the mail, he hadn't mentioned a word of it to Sean. For a moment, he considered telling Sean all about it right now, but Kuai rejected that idea, deciding it would take way too long to explain, and that they needed to head out on the road soon.

"What was that, babe?" Sean asked at Kuai, a curious but still-tired look on his face.

"Uh..." Kuai had a mini-panic attack as he thought about what he could say instead of talking about the pendant. "I said I guess he has pent-up energy inside of him that he just has to get out somehow. You know how it is with kids."

"Not really," Sean said as he got up and walked over to the bathroom inside their room. "That's more your department, Mr. Tao." He grinned as he stepped out of view, and Kuai felt his insides flutter when Sean called him that. He breathed a sigh of relief, thankful that Sean wasn't too suspicious of anything that had happened with him or Makani.

The rest of the morning went fairly smoothly, Kuai heading downstairs to make some scrambled eggs for the other two. After they finished, Sean headed upstairs for some last minute preparations. Makani started to clear off the table and brought the plates to the sink, while Kuai cleaned the pan and mixing bowl, standing next to him. "Hey, Kuai?" Makani asked while he rinsed the dishes, "when do you think you'll be able to grow me to twelve feet again like we were talking about last night?"

Kuai repressed a growing laugh. Up for less than an hour, and already he wants to grow again, he thought. "Well," he said as he turned to Makani, leaning against the sink, "you'll probably want me to wait until we get to Springfield. I don't think my Mazda would be able to fit a twelve-foot-tall boy, even with you having the entire backseat to yourself."

Laughing, Makani nodded. "Okay, we'll wait until we get there. But can you do it right as soon as I step out of the car. Please, Kuai?" Makani looked up at him with the biggest eyes Kuai had ever seen on a boy his age. He couldn't say no to that face.

"Sure," Kuai ruffled up Makani's long dark-brown hair, "the instant you set foot in the parking lot, you'll be twelve feet again. Give or take a few seconds."

Makani pumped his fist. "Yeah! Now I'm REALLY excited!" He started to jump up and down a little as he brought the plates to the dishwasher and set them inside.

Kuai loved the boy's enthusiasm, but he realized he would have to temper it a bit if they were going to keep the secret of the pendant to themselves. Not only would there be all the thousands of people at the fair to think of, but Sean was going to be with them all day too.

"Hey, Makani, listen." Kuai made sure Makani was looking at him before he continued. "Remember that right now you are the only person besides myself who knows about the pendant and what it could do. Not even Sean knows."

"You mean you haven't told him anything about it yet?" Makani seemed a little surprised to find out this information.

Kuai shook his head, a little embarrassed. "Nope. I'm not so sure what he'd say or do if he were to find out. I'll tell him eventually, I'm sure, but for now I'd like for him or anyone else to remain unaware of the pendant's existence. For now."

Makani thought about this for a second before agreeing. "Okay, that's no big deal. You said that one of the switches there makes everyone else think that I've always been whatever size I am at the time, right? So you could grow me to be twelve feet tall, or a hundred feet tall, or even five hundred, and everyone would think I've always been that huge." Makani looked up for a second, allowing himself to get lost a little in that fantasy. "Imagine! Everyone thinking that I grew up my entire childhood being the size of a skyscraper!"

Kuai chuckled. By the time this is all over, who knows what could happen, he thought to himself.

15111111111221111122121111121.content:
Ten minutes later, they were on the road, heading up I-93 towards downtown Boston, then merging onto I-90 west towards Springfield. As Kuai drove with Sean fiddling with his phone in the passenger seat next to him, he kept glancing back to Makani, who was sprawled across the back seat, listening to his iPod and reading a book for school at the same time. He's such an interesting kid, Kuai thought, incredibly mature for his age, but at the same time still hanging onto a childish sense of fantasy and delight. I guess that's why I was drawn to him in the first place; he's almost exactly like me in those ways.

Encountering no traffic on the drive, they actually arrived at the fairgrounds at 9:38, a few minutes earlier than Kuai had anticipated. Keeping his word from earlier, as soon as Makani opened the door and jumped out of the backseat of the car, Kuai imagined him growing four feet taller, and the boy's body followed suit. A huge grin formed across Makani's mouth as he felt his body tingling and stretching higher above Kuai, Sean, and everyone else, but he remained silent, not wanting to alert anyone to what was happening and possibly get Kuai in trouble with them. Finally, he stopped growing when he reached twelve feet tall. The top of Sean's head was not quite level with Makani's belt, and Kuai didn't come up much past the boy's belly button. The youngster walked in between the two adults, getting lots of stares from other fairgoers.

As they got in line at the admission gates, Kuai noticed that the price for a child twelve or under was five bucks less than the price for an adult ticket. At first, he thought about asking Makani if he could temporarily shrink him down under six feet tall so the ticket seller would believe he was twelve years old, but as he was just about to open his mouth, he looked up at Makani's face and realized how much more enthusiastic the boy had gotten just within the past few minutes since his increase to twelve feet tall. Kuai figured it was worth the extra five bucks he'd have to pay just to keep that momentum going.

Stepping up next to the window, Kuai pulled out his wallet. "Three adult tickets, please," he said to the elderly lady manning the booth.

"Would you like to add on tickets to see Reba McEntire tonight in concert at the Comcast Arena Stage?" the lady asked.

"Reba McEntire?" Makani scrunched up his nose. "Who's she?"

"She's a country music star," Kuai informed him. "I don't actually know any of her songs, though."

"Country?!" Makani pinched his nose shut in playful disgust. "Eeeww, no thanks!"

"Just the fair tickets would be fine, then," Kuai replied to the lady.

As he handed the money over, Sean's eyes suddenly lit up, and he grabbed Kuai's arm in dramatic fashion. "But wait, guys! What if it's actually Kenan Thompson in a wig?!"

He paused, with a huge goofy grin on his face, as if he was expecting the other two guys to start laughing. When they didn't, he said, "C'mon, guys, haven't you seen that SNL Short?"

Rolling his eyes, Kuai shook his head, taking the tickets and fair map the lady had handed him. "No, Sean, I doubt that we have. I don't get to catch up on as much television as you do. Being a teacher doesn't leave me with a lot of free time."

"Fine, then, forget it." Sean crossed his arms and turned away, pouting slightly. Kuai ignored him for a minute, knowing that he would get over it by the time the guys were inside the fair gates, which he did.

Once inside, Makani literally bounced with excitement, seeing all the bright signs and lights flashing. He breathed deeply, taking in the mixture of various aromas and smells (some pleasing, some not-so-pleasing). Kuai could notice the boy's mouth starting to water, and he checked his wallet again, making sure that he had enough cash to pay for any food that the massive Hawaiian boy and his twice-as-big stomach would require.

"Let's go to the midway!" Makani pointed towards the roller coaster and ferris wheel that rose above the other buildings near the back of the fairgrounds.

Without waiting for an answer, he quickly started heading in that direction, leaving Kuai and Sean standing in place, looking down and examining the map. When Kuai looked up and noticed Makani's head and upper body rising above the rest of the crowd some two hundred feet ahead of them, he panicked slightly and yelled out, "HEY! Makani!"

The boy didn't seem to hear him, so he and Sean sprinted to catch up with him, finally grabbing the edge of his shirt and stopping him, causing Makani to turn around. "What's the matter?" he asked, with a concerned and apprehensive look on his face.

"Nothing," Kuai huffed, trying to catch his breath from sprinting. "It's just that..." He wheezed again, realizing that Makani could really cover some distance quickly at this size, with those longer legs of his. "...The midway isn't open for another hour or so. Besides, the rides and games there are always more fun to do in the late afternoon and evening. Think of it as an end-cap, a great way to finish the day."

"Oh... okay!" After a few moments of contemplation, Makani seemed to understand the reasoning. "Well then, where should we head to first?"

They were standing almost in the exact middle of the fairgrounds, so they looked around, turning in all directions and trying to see what appeared as if it would be the most interesting thing to do. Finally, they decided on...

151111111112211111221211111211.content:
"Let's walk around the Avenue of the States" Kuai suggested, as they turned towards the area where many historic buildings from the New England states were on display. Already, Makani had a hard time getting through the doors of the buildings, since he was so big and tall. Kuai had to adjust his height and shrink him down so he could walk through the door before growing him back again, but the boy didn't mind having to go through these constant little growth and shrinking spurts.

When they were wandering around outside again, Kuai heard a familiar voice call out his name.

"Kuai? Is that you?"

He turned around and recognized Stan, an old friend from school, whom he hadn't seen for years until now.

"Stanley Stevens? Oh my goodness! How are you?"

"Kuai? What's going on, my friend? Are you still teaching? How do you like my little fair, huh?" the short, chubby man in the three piece suit asked.

"Yes, I'm teaching math at the academy. This here is Makani, one of my students!" Kuai said, as he allowed Makani and Stan to shake hands. “Oh, I love it here! So, are you running this place?”

"Wow! What a big boy! Almost like what I'm looking for!" Stan said. “Yeah, I’m in charge here!”

"What do you mean?" Kuai asked him.

"Well, I was hoping to find a giant dude or a muscle man, just to have as an attraction for the weekend. My regular muscle guy is doing a show in Chicago so I need a substitute." Stan explained.

"Well, see Makani over here? He's pretty big, right? I can actually make him grow even bigger than he is now!" Kuai whispered in his ear. "I got a pendant which can change the boy's size!"

“Yeah! Kuai can make me REALLY BIG!” Makani added. “Much bigger than this!”

"Really? I was kinda hoping for a giant... Like a really BIG guy.... One who could hold people in the palm of his hand. Man, could you make him that big?" Stan asked him. “I know that is asking a bit much… I must be asking the impossible, right?”

"What? Me? A giant? Oh yeah!" Makani said excitedly.

Kuai could tell where this was going. Makani was smiling from ear to ear.

"How big do you want him to be and where do you want him to be at?" Kuai asked him.

"Let me take you to a big grassy field near the back of the park. All he has to do is sit there and let people sit on his hand and climb up his legs. Make him like fifty feet tall! Is that possible?"

They walked over to a large grassy area which was covered by a huge oak tree. Makani then stood near the center of the area and waited as Kuai adjusted the settings on the pendant so that everyone could see the growth and so that Makani's clothes would grow with him.

Them, the twelve foot tall boy started getting bigger and bigger, experiencing the most intense growth spurt he has ever had. With a huge grin on his face, others gathered around as the boy's growing legs propelled him higher and higher. His torso grew bigger, wider and taller while his arms became longer. His feet grew as well, and his muscles exploded with outrageous growth all at once. Kuai realized that he was now making Makani into the biggest and strongest human being on earth!

Makani just grinned as the growth stopped. Looking down, people just seemed like action figures to him. He was a true giant now, towering over buildings before him. As he sat down, leaning with his back against the oak tree, a crowd already began to form. People wanted to meet the giant boy and sit on the palm of his hand and enjoy the view from his shoulders. What a spectacular sight!

“Kuai! You crazy dog! How did you do that?” Stanley cheered. “Look at that kid! That was just amazing!”

“How long does he need to stay there?” Kuai asked him then.

“Oh, just for two hours. I figured that would be long enough for this afternoon. But, could you bring him back here by tomorrow?”

“Yeah! We’re here for the whole weekend!” Kuai grinned. “Plus, Makani is a great kid. He’s very mature, which is why he makes a great giant! The boy is just made to be big!”

Kuai and Stanley looked on as Makani lowered his hand to the ground and allowed people to step on the palm of his hand. Then he would raise his hand to his other shoulder, so that they could climb on to his big, broad shoulder and sit on them for a few minutes. Then, he would lower them to his giant thighs, where they would walk around and explore his enormous legs, until they could reach a small staircase and get back to the ground below.

Kuai quickly used his cell phone to take a picture of the titanic Hawaiian boy who was happily entertaining the people like they were small action figures. Then, he placed a call to his friend Nick in California, just after he emailed that photo to him.

“My goodness, Kuai! You made that boy gigantic!” Nick exclaimed.

“He is the star attraction at the fair right now, Nick! The crowd loves him!” Kuai explained. “Not only that, I noticed something while I was growing him…”

“What is that?”

“How easy it was! I mean, I expected that I would have needed to concentrate harder on making the boy grow since I was planning on making him so big, but it was just so incredibly easy! I mean… I just pictured him becoming a giant and BAM! The kid just exploded in size and muscle! His body just shot UP like you wouldn’t believe! It’s like, every time I make him grow, it seems to be getting a LOT easier!”

“Well, you’ve already changed him a few times, is that correct?” Nick asked him.

“Yeah, about a dozen times already!”

“Well, the pendant pretty much has all of Makani’s physical properties saved by now. Furthermore, the kid’s body has pretty much adjusted to growing and shrinking thanks to the pendant. I mean, you can shrink or grow just about any part of the kid’s body with your eyes closed by now! You can increase his muscles or make his legs grow longer… You can change him in any way you want to, by now!”

“It’s not going to hurt him, will it?” Kuai asked, feeling a bit concerned.

“Not at all. I don’t even think Makani even feels the changes anymore. He doesn’t even notice it! You can grow him another set of biceps if you wanted, or a second set of legs! Just remember, if you use the pendant a lot, you might drain the battery sooner and it will take a few hours for the pendant to charge!” Nick warned him.

“Okay! Thanks Nick!” Kuai said, before hanging up.

Kuai and Sean then wandered around the fair, occasionally checking up on the giant Hawaiian boy, who was having more than enough fun on his own by letting people sit on his hands on shoulders and on his legs while he just looked down at the crowd below…

1511111111122112.content:
Two rapid beeps sounded from the intercom. “Mister Tao?”

Kuai immediately recognized the older woman’s voice. “Yes ma’am?” he called out, looking in the direction of the speaker.

“Excuse this interruption,” the secretary’s voice crackled, “Could you please report to Dr. Yates’ office as soon as possible. He would like a word with you.”

“The middle school principal?” Kuai gulped in his thoughts. “I’ll be right there,” he said.

“Thank you, Mr. Tao. I will inform him that you are on your way.”

CLICK. 

Standing in silence once more, Kuai’s mind began to rush. Teachers dislike getting unexpectedly called to the principal’s office almost as much as students do, if not more-so. At least he didn't have to travel to the main administrative building in the center of campus to see the headmaster, who oversaw the entire academy.

Kuai rarely got in trouble. On some occasions, Dr. Yates asked him to tone down his intensively competitive nature while coaching. However, since the Wellington Academy’s Crimson Knights were usually victorious even over the much larger public schools, Kuai had earned some latitude to be more— expressive.

Then the image of Tyler up against the lockers suddenly flashed into Kuai's mind. “This couldn’t have something to do with the fight earlier, could it? What if the principal was suspicious about my involvement in the situation? There are cameras all over campus. I can’t just lie and say, ‘I wasn’t there.’”

Kuai calmed his nerves, headed out the door, and locked up his classroom. The hall seemed unusually quiet and empty. A long corridor with pristine, freshly painted white walls stretched down for quite a distance. A pair of large staircases at either end of the hall were overlooked by two, large, double pained windows. All of the lockers neatly lined the wide corridor with their pristine shape and crimson tint. That is, except for two lockers near the end of the hall closest to Kuai’s classroom. Kuai ran his hand along the wrinkled contour of the metal. Every curve and twist of the metal reminded him of the incident from fourth period. It took both of the top lockers to cradle Tyler’s enormous back, barely holding him up against his would-be attackers.

Kuai gulped again, his mind still unnerved by this sudden summons. He managed to keep his head high only to be forced to duck it down again a moment later. None of the doorways were tall enough to fit Kuai when he stood upright. And only double doors or larger could fit Kuai squarely through their opening Kuai followed the winding staircase, bathed in sunlight and pausing on the first landing. Campus at midday was a breathtaking sight. The enormous panes of glass could clearly see the entire northeast side of campus. 

Rays of light scattered through the trees over the lush campus. Just beyond a shaded grove, neatly trimmed plants and polished wooden benches stood the single story elementary building; the only single story building on the Wellington’s entire campus. Kuai could even hear the faint chirp of birds over the quiet hum of central air.

He loved being outside. Perhaps that’s why Kuai always loved sports so much, that and the thirst to win at a physical contest. Kuai finished his descent to the first floor, bound for Dr. Yates’ office. He barely reached the lobby’s entrance, guarded by a pair of double oak doors, when he heard raised voices coming from the science hall beyond. Kuai ducked toward Dr. Yates’ office, peeking through one of the many windows. The secretary who buzzed him earlier hadn’t seen him yet.

Kuai rounded past the office, leaving the well-furnished, although stale, lobby to investigate. Halfway down the science hall, just off the other side of the lobby, stood a furious teacher and his student. Kuai could now make out more clearly what they were saying.

“—and what do you think gives you the right to interrupt my class, pencil neck! On the first day of school no less!” an older man bellowed.

“But sir—“ a younger voice defended.

“No buts, young man! What part of 'remain silent' do you and these other seventh-grade morons not seem to understand?! It’s a wonder I made it through last year’s bunch; now you're aiming to top them on the first day of classes. Leave it to a pencil neck like you—”

The onslaught continued. Kuai didn’t have to listen to understand what was going on. He stood at the end of the hall as discretely as a 6’9” muscle bound Asian could, partially shrouded by a pair of lockers. He peeked over the top of the metal easily and recognized the teacher immediately; a particularly disgruntled middle-aged teacher that Kuai felt should have left the profession long ago.

It was more difficult for Kuai to get a good look at the kid. He had short brown hair and kept adjusting what appeared to be a large pair of glasses hanging off his nose. Then he noticed something odd. “This kid is as tall as his teacher. He could look him right in the eye if he wanted too. Must be at least six feet tall.”

It finally clicked. “Wait a second,” Kuai thought, “How many seventh graders are that big? It’s Kevin!”

Sure enough, the mousy child from Kuai’s first period class was the one being relentlessly chewed out by his science teacher. Kuai didn’t fully understand why he was so upset, but he didn’t really care. He accepted the need to be heavy-handed sometimes; he was a coach, after all. But this guy kept personally attacking Kevin, just because he could. Kuai felt his heart begin to race. His eyes narrowed; his hand tightly gripped the pendant. He had had enough! “Yell at this— asshole.” 

Kevin’s body swelled as the teacher continued to yell. All of his muscles burst to life with growing size and thickening strength. His swimmer’s build reshaped into that of a rock-solid middleweight wrestler. Kevin’s chest puffed out, his back widened and his legs bulged even larger under clothes that were being magically forced to keep up with his growth.

Kuai also inched Kevin up about three inches more, making him half a head taller than his teacher. Kuai watched the angered science teacher lose his nerve as Kevin grew more impressive; 6’3”, 12 years old and ripped with strength. Kevin’s body now looked even more impressive than Makani’s, but not by much.

Kevin’s growth finally slowed. He kept his head tilted down, but now his enormous green eyes were right in line with his teacher’s face. Kuai could hear the potbellied teacher clear his throat. “And you stay out here until you can control yourself in class. Understand?” the teacher’s voice forcefully shook Like an angry dog with no teeth.

“Yes—sir.” Kevin grumbled coldly.

The classroom door opened and shut quickly, leaving Kevin all alone. He threw his broadened back against a pair of lockers and sank to the ground. “About time that old coot left!” Kuai thought to himself, his body temperature slowly returning to normal. “But should I go over there and talk with Kevin, or get to the office? After all, Dr. Yates isn’t known for his patience…”
1511111111122112.title: A Rough Day

choices: Dr. Yates meets Kuai in the reception office & is furious about having to wait!
Dr. Yates didn't notice, distracted by working with a student in his office.
15111111111221122.content:
Kuai couldn't leave Kevin there. He may be huge, but he was still a kid. And any person would be feeling awful after being yelled at like that. Kuai made his way to Kevin, who had tucked his head in between his thick, tan arms and huge legs which were straddled apart. Kuai heard soft muffled sounds coming from the child.

He stood there a moment, mere feet away from Kevin, unsure of what to say. Kuai’s eyes wandered, getting a chance to soak in all of his changes up close and personal. Kevin’s smooth skin rippled at every little flex of his body. His clothes had grown with him, but they still pulled around the largest bulges. Finally Kuai found the words and spoke. “Rough day, Kevin?”

The huge boy shot his head straight up in the air, momentarily forgetting the tears and sweat that still drenched his face. “Mr. Tao!” His eyes shot around nervously; he quickly motioned to stand.

“It’s alright, Kevin. You can remain seated.”

Kevin looked upon Kuai with nervousness and appreciation. “Please. Don’t look at me, Mr. Tao! My face—it must be—“

Kevin brought his mighty arm up to wipe and cover his face. His other hand pulled his legs close, curling him into more of a ball. Kuai slowly knelt next to Kevin, looking through his muscles, speaking directly into the boy’s huge green eyes. “You’re face is fine Kevin. I would be upset too if something like that happened to me.”

Kevin dropped his arm, the pain in his eyes magnified. He sniffled. “You heard all of it?”

Embarrassment filled his pained face, but Kevin didn’t look away. Kuai remained as soft and caring as he knew how, only nodding his head once in response.

Kevin sniffled in pain once more, quickly hiding his head underneath his arms again. It was amazing his heavy glasses didn’t fly off his nose. “Oh great! Just—“

Kevin’s head whipped around furiously before burrowing back into his arms. The rest of Kevin’s muffled words were lost between his arms and legs, choked by another painful sob. It seemed he wanted desperately to hide, but had nowhere to go. Kuai’s voice darkened. “You were being treated unacceptably, no matter what happened.” 

Kevin threw his head back up to Kuai’s. “Really? I mean, I… I was thrown out of class. Y-you saw.”

“It depends on what happened. But no matter what it was, he should never have demeaned you with malicious name-calling.”

Kevin huffed, wiping his face clean with his arm. “Those are some of the nicer names I have ever been called. Being so tall and once in my life being so thin— people think of some pretty cruel things to call you.”

Kuai felt his heart skip a beat. “You—were thin?” Had Kevin somehow become aware of Kuai's changes? 

Kevin bobbed his head, a hint of a smile glistened. “I know. Hard to believe right?” 

Kevin bit his lip and his eyes fluttered about. “It’s just…” Kevin tried to speak, but the words would get tangled up in his tongue. Nervous as ever, Kevin fought through it to tell Kuai part of his story. “There was a time wh-when I was just lanky and tall. I was… am, the outsider.”

Kevin took deep breaths, expanding his chest into his knees. Speaking so candidly was obviously difficult and Kuai was patient as ever as he watched Kevin piece together his thoughts. Finally, the nervous hulk continued. “People want nothing to do with me. No matter what. I put on weight. I got b-bigger. But they never changed. It was always the same.”

The longer Kevin spoke, the easier it became for the words to form. The only difficulty now was how emotional these words made Kevin feel. “If they aren’t hissing about my glasses, then it’s my height. If it’s not my height, then it’s my voice. One thing after another on constant repeat, day in and day out for all my life.”

Tears returned to his cheeks, but his eyes never blinked. They were glued to Kuai in a way he couldn’t do minutes before. Kevin gulped, exhaling uneven breaths. “Once an outsider, always an outsider.”

Kuai sighed, relieved to hear Kevin believed he had come by his size naturally, but still burdened by a different feeling. This was the third time a student had recounted a painful past to him, and it hurt. Each story Kuai heard hurt him more and more to listen to. A whole lifetime of pain hid behind their youthful features and their young years, but that didn’t make them suffer any less. Kuai now knew why he had been drawn to Kevin so many hours earlier. Tyler, Makani and Kevin were all outcasts. Each bore their own secret weight, unable to shrug it off or to shoulder it anymore. Kuai knew this pain. Their pain was his pain too.

“Listen Kevin—“ Kuai breathed in, “Those people may think whatever they like. A long time ago, people thought and said some fairly mean things about me as well, but—“ he gulped, “I pressed on. I found people who cared for me because of who I was, not because of who they wanted me to be. From then on, I have cherished only having to be myself and being loved by the few people I care about for it.

“In time, I know you will find people just like that, Kevin. There are people out there who will love and care for you exactly the way you are. And until you find them all, I want you to know that I will always be in your corner, looking out for you. Do you understand?”

Kuai spoke with such force and sincerity, causing Kevin’s eyes to widen even further than Kuai thought possible. His jaw slackened and he nodded his head with long slow stokes. Kaui could see all of his muscles tense up and bulge. Kevin had a deep and profound reaction to Kuai’s sincerity. Even more than either knew.

Kuai stood, the boy's emerald eyes following him through the coke-bottle lenses. He extended his hand and slowly helped Kevin up to his feet. Kevin’s strength had certainly grown, and hopefully some of that strength would soon bloom on the inside now, rather than just the outside. Perhaps in time, his body could reflect the strength within. Yet another boy Kuai was sure he wanted to help. 

No. He needed to help.

Kevin wiped his face one final time, although it was still flushed, especially around the cheeks. “Are you ready to get back in there Kevin?”

Kevin gave Kuai the same doe-eyed look from this morning and floated back inside. “Yes, sir,” he said as he closed the door.

Kuai hunched down and looked through the tall rectangular window on the door. He saw the middle aged teacher lecturing gruffly as ever. His eyes caught sight of Kevin once more, forcing him to stumble before continuing. Kuai let out a sly grin. “And if I ever catch you yelling at one of MY kids again—“ he gripped the pendant, “I will find out just what this thing can do!”

Kuai stood straight back up and hurried down the hall. Dr. Yates was still waiting. “How long does it take for me to get from my classroom to the first floor, anyway?” Kuai thought. “It’s not like I had to walk to the headmaster’s office in the central building.”

Kuai hurried through the lobby and took a breath, ready to face whatever Dr. Yates needed to see him for.

151111111112211222.content:
Kuai walked up to the desk where the secretary sat, the older grey-haired woman glancing back and forth between a large stack of papers and the computer monitor in front of her, her hands never deviating from the keyboard. He stood at her desk, waiting for a greeting that never came. "It's not like she can't see me," Kuai thought to himself, beginning to tap his foot. Finally he cleared his throat, saying, "Sorry I'm late, Barbara."

"Oh, Mr. Tao," a slightly smug smile formed on the secretary's lips without her eyes ever leaving her work. "What's your excuse this time?"

Kuai shook his head. "No excuse. I just got distracted along the way."

He heard a slight "tsk"-ing sound come from her lips, "Well," she said, "lucky for you Keith Larson stopped by and Dr. Yates is still chatting with him. You can go ahead and head on in, though; he told me he wanted to see you as soon as possible."

Kuai nodded and stepped down a small hallway towards the ornate wooden door of the principal's office. Knowing that Keith Larson waited for him inside didn't exactly help his apprehension. The eighth-grader was the perfect example of the kind of student at Wellington that Kuai despised: rich, stuck-up, and extremely condescending, even to his teachers. He had been elected president of the middle school student council both in 7th and 8th grades (probably having bought the election, Kuai figured), and always had his nose in every corner of the school's business. It didn't help matters that Keith's father sat on the board of directors for the school and that his family was instrumental in the school's founding, even having the elementary school building named after them.

As he stopped in front of the half-open door, he could hear Keith's muffled voice in some sort of discussion with the principal. Kuai started thinking of the last time he had come to this office, when he had gotten in a bit of trouble at the end of last year. He had taught Keith in seventh grade Honors Pre-Algebra, and had given the boy the grade that his shoddy homework and test scores deserved and added up to: a C minus. That's when the boy's father began raining down on him the holy hellfire that only a multimillionaire could deliver, making threatening calls and emails to the teacher (which went unanswered), eventually barging into the school building and confronting Kuai face-to-face. After Kuai didn't budge, Mr. Larson tried to go over his head to the principal. A bitter tug-of-war ensued between Kuai and Dr. Yates about raising the boy's score, but he eventually got Dr. Yates to agree with him, and the C minus remained, though the battle had caused the relationship between the teacher and the principal to become strained. He only hoped that this year could start off on a better note.

Bracing himself for whatever was about to happen, he lightly rapped on the door. "Come in," he heard Dr. Yates' booming voice call from inside. He stepped through the door and into the office. The decoration in Dr. Yates' office was impressive, with darkly-painted walls, golden trim and a vaulted ceiling. Large oak bookshelves lined the room, filled with volumes on subjects ranging from education principles and child psychology to more intense fare like military history. In the center of one side of the office was Dr. Yates' framed diplomas from both West Point and Columbia University; on the opposite was a decades-old portrait of the principal wearing his Army dress uniform, along with several framed medals and commendations.

Kuai knew (along with every other teacher) Dr. Yates' storied history as an officer in the Army, and the decision after retiring from the military to obtain a Ph.D. in Education Leadership and enter the world of school administration. He had started as middle school principal at Wellington the year before Kuai joined the faculty, and had developed a reputation amongst teachers and students alike as a tough but fair leader who liked to give inspiring speeches that had a tendency to drag on just a bit too long, and who would rarely call students or teachers by their first names and expected them to respond likewise. Kuai couldn't help but to admire and respect the man for all that he had accomplished in his life, but the two continued to find themselves on the opposite sides of many issues that arose, butting heads occasionally.

"Ah, Mr. Tao," Dr. Yates said, standing as the teacher entered, "thank you for coming down."

Kuai nodded at the principal, looking at him eye-to-eye, the only person in the school who he didn't have to tilt his head far down to do that (well, except for Tyler now, of course). Even though the broad-shouldered African-American man stood slightly shorter than Kuai at six foot six, he carried himself with a presence that could be both impressive and intimidating, even to the larger Asian teacher. Dr. Yates' face had a energy to its expressions that hid his true age (which Kuai didn't know exactly but guessed had to be over sixty). His smooth, mostly wrinkle-free skin and clean-shaven head helped contribute to that effect, the only signs of advancement being slight streaks of grey in his otherwise black, impeccably-trimmed mustache, and the thin-framed reading glasses that stuck out slightly in his jacket pocket. Kuai had never seen the principal in anything other than a sharply-pressed suit, even when he was attending the basketball games Kuai coached. The one he now wore looked particularly striking, a jet-black suit with dark purple pinstripes, matched with a diagonally-striped black and violet tie.

Trying to suppress a slight sense of nervousness that had set in, Kuai swallowed as silently as he could. "You wanted to see me?"

"Yes, sit down, please," Dr. Yates motioned to one of the chairs across from his desk, the only empty one there, since Keith was sitting in the other. "I just was finishing up with Mr. Larson, who had come by to make sure the school had adequately budgeted enough funds for the student council's planned activities this semester. I assured him that we most certainly have." Kuai recognized the concealed glimmer of contempt in the principal's eyes, knowing that Dr. Yates disliked dealing with the boy and his pesky father as much as the rest of the faculty did.

Looking over at the student, Kuai noticed that Keith seemed to have totally ignored the teacher's entrance into the room. "After what I went through with him last year, I wouldn't expect any less from him," Kuai thought. The fair-skinned, red-haired boy was dressed in the optional school blazer with the Wellington Academy logo on its left breast pocket (as he always was). Even now, sitting across from Dr. Yates, he had an air of superiority about him that repelled Kuai nearly immediately. The teacher thought about using the pendant right here and now to cut this boy down to size (literally), but he restrained himself, realizing that may have something to do with why he got called to the office in the first place.

Keith rose to his feet as Kuai sat down, sticking out his hand to shake Dr. Yates'. "Well, I'm certainly glad we have all that straightened out," he said as he forced a very fake-looking smile. "I wouldn't want the students of Wellington Academy to not be receiving their fair share."

"As would I," Dr. Yates returned, stone-faced. "Good day, Mr. Larson."

The boy stepped behind Kuai's chair, still ignoring the teacher's presence, and left the room. Dr. Yates walked over to the door and shut it completely behind him, sighing when it had closed. "Thank God that's over with," he thought. "Dealing with that boy and his damn father is harder than kissing ass to a four-star general."

"Just be glad you only have to deal with him every week or two," Kuai said, grinning slightly. "I had him in class every day."

"Don't remind me," Dr. Yates replied as he returned to the plush leather chair behind his large mahogany desk. "but you didn't have to also deal with appeasing a father who could make a motion at any time to have you removed from leadership. I gotta say, sometimes the blood in this school can run too blue for my tastes."

Kuai nodded in agreement. After a few seconds of silence, he breathed deeply. Might as well get it over with, he thought. "So, Dr. Yates, what did you call me down to your office for?"

Kuai's fears were confirmed when Dr. Yates' eyebrows furrowed slightly, and the principal crossed his arms on the desk and leaned forward. "Look, Mr. Tao," he started, "you know as well as I do that the thing I dislike most, more than pain-in-the-ass parents, more than firing underperforming teachers, more than any of the other stresses my role in administration throws at me, is violence in my school halls. Not only does it create extra paperwork that someone has to end up doing, not only does it potentially threaten to raise our insurance premiums..." He paused, closing his eyes and breathing in deeply, seemingly accessing some deep-seated emotion or personal history. He then looked straight back at Kuai, continuing "...but, more importantly, it can lead to things that are far far worse for the very kids that we are here to protect and educate. Believe me, I know."

Kuai felt his cheeks begin to grow a little flush and he slumped slightly in his chair. "I understand completely, sir. And I agree."

Dr. Yates picked up a coffee mug off of his desk and took a sip before continuing. "I'm glad you do agree with me, Mr. Tao. But it troubles me when a fight breaks out in the school halls, and I hear that a teacher is witness to the event, but doesn't do anything to stop it. I understand that's what happened today."

"But--" Kuai stopped himself, realizing that nothing he could say here would make him look any better in the principal's eyes. Dr. Yates wouldn't accept the excuse of being trapped by the crowds of students, as he would expect a teacher of Kuai's size and strength of presence to have been able to quickly yell and clear a path straight to the boys. And Kuai couldn't exactly say that he actually did help resolve the situation by using the pendant to transform the bullies from oversized goons to shrimpy little punks, could he? Of course not. Rubbing his eyes gently, Kuai attempted to clear his mind, at the same time trying to come up with the best answer he could give. "Yes, sir," he said as he looked back up at Dr. Yates, "you're right. The halls were crowded, and I was hoping things wouldn't get as bad as they ended up getting, but I should've stepped in sooner. I apologize for that."

Nodding in silent acceptance, Dr. Yates rose to his feet, turning around and pacing while looking at his back wall, continuing to talk. "Now, I don't care about the damage to school property. We have plenty in the budget this year to be able to replace a locker or two. And from the other teachers and students that I've interviewed, I understand that there were no serious injuries to any of the involved parties." He turned back to face Kuai, coming around to the other side of the desk and leaning against it slightly. "There are a few things I'd like to go over with you, though, just to make sure we're on the same page."

"Okay," Kuai leaned back in his chair a little and tried to look as professional as possible. "I'm open for any advice you have for me."

Sliding his glasses from his jacket pocket and putting them on, Dr. Yates then pulled a manilla file folder from a stack on his desk, reading it before continuing. "First, one of the students who was involved in the fight, Tyler Phillips." He looked back at Kuai, his eyes peering over the tops of the glasses. "He was just coming from your third period math class. Is that correct?"

"Yes."

Dr. Yates flipped another page on his list. "He's an extraordinarily tall boy, if I recall from last year. Nearly as tall as you, correct?

Gulping slightly, Kuai hoped Dr. Yates wouldn't dwell on this subject too much and start to unravel the logic of the reality Kuai and the pendant had constructed. "More or less," he finally answered, attempting to be as neutral as possible.

The principal didn't seem to be confused about this, merely accepting it as another fact about the boy. He chuckled slightly, the hints of a smile forming at the corners of his lips. "I can't imagine why such short, slender boys would start to harass someone that size. Do you have any idea what instigated the fight, Mr. Tao?"

"Well," Kuai thought back to the scene in the hallway for a moment, "I believe Tyler may have accidentally bumped into one of the other boys in passing, and that boy took offense to it."

"I see," Dr. Yates nodded. He remained silent for a moment. "Bullies are bullies; they'll find any excuse they can to pick on someone, though usually they aim for smaller targets. I'm more concerned about Mr. Phillips, though. Did you notice anything unusual about him during class? Or did he say anything to you?"

Kuai did his best to appear calm as he recalled vividly the conversations he had with Tyler in his room after class as well as in the hallway after the fight. He couldn't tell Dr. Yates about all that, could he? Even Tyler's recent ADHD diagnosis wasn't yet known by anyone at the school besides him, including (Kuai presumed) the administration. It might not be the most shocking thing in the world, but it was something Tyler had told him in trust. Unless Tyler was in physical or emotional danger, Kuai could not imagine ever violating that trust, even with his boss. Taking a deep breath, he shook his head. "We chatted a bit about what we were going to be covering this year in class, but nothing like that came up." One thing popped into Kuai's mind, something that he had no trouble sharing (or bragging about). "Oh! He did tell me he was a UCLA fan. He seemed pretty thrilled when he saw my jersey and found out I played for them."

Dr. Yates began to smile a little more broadly. "You know," he said, "I'm sure you have a lot you could teach Mr. Phillips, about math as well as about living in a world that was designed for those a foot shorter than you. It sounds like he's already found something to connect with you on in his love for the Bruins; I'd recommend you seize that opportunity and try to establish more things in common in order to establish a deeper bond. Try to identify with him on a more personal level; see if you can try to understand him and get him to understand you. I think if you do that, he'll open up to you, and we might be able to avoid situations like this in the future."

"Way ahead of you," Kuai thought as he grinned. "That's a good idea, sir," he said aloud. "I'll get on that immediately."

"Good, sounds like we have a battle plan." Dr. Yates said as he brought his hand up to shake. Kuai rose to his feet. As he clasped Dr. Yates' hand, however, the principal's expression became serious once again. "And, Mr. Tao, if something like this were to happen again, and you were found to be standing idly by a second time, trust me when I say that our conversation would be much different than the one we're having today. Do you understand?"

He let go of Kuai's hand as a slight sense of uncomfortableness began to set in for the teacher. "Y-yes, Dr. Yates, I understand. I can promise that it won't happen again."

"Thank you, Mr. Tao." Dr. Yates said. "That will be all." Sitting back down at his desk, Dr. Yates picked up another file and began reading it in silence. Kuai turned around and left the office, his heartbeat seemingly accelerated, wondering inside if he would be able to keep the promise he had just made.

As he stepped back into the lobby, he noticed that Keith Larson was still there, chatting with Barbara, the secretary, who looked desperate for someone to rescue her. Kuai walked up to the two, hoping his arrival would cause the boy to move along.

Instead, though, Keith just looked up at the teacher, a somewhat sour expression on his face. It seemed to Kuai that the boy's proper aristocratic upbringing was the only thing keeping him from lunging at the teacher and trying to choke him, despite the substantial height difference between them. Instead, though, Keith just tilted his head to the side, making eye contact with Kuai for the first time today. "Mr. Tao," he said, grimacing as he did.

"Keith," Kuai replied, responding in just a slightly more professional manner.

"Well," Keith turned back to the secretary, "I'll just be on my way, Barbara. Please make sure that message gets to my father before the end of the school day." He turned and walked out of the office, Kuai watching him as he did.

"What does he think I am," Barbara scoffed, "his message service? That boy is just the kind of thing that's wrong with this school."

Kuai nodded in agreement, stepping out of the hallway and watching the boy head to the stairs. "I shouldn't do anything drastic," he thought to himself as he casually pulled out the pendant, "but that's no reason for me not to have a little fun." As Keith started to round the corner, Kuai imagined him quickly growing by two-and-a-half feet, making him about three inches taller than the door he was passing through. Keith's body immediately shot upwards, growing substantially bigger in a flash, until his head banged against the doorframe with a loud CLANG.

"Owwww," he heard Keith say as the boy rubbed his head. "Why can't these blasted doors be any taller?"

Chuckling to himself, Kuai quickly imagined Keith back down to normal height and headed the opposite direction, towards the staircase leading up to his classroom. Looking at the clock in the hall, Kuai noticed that the final bell was just about to ring. Hurrying back to his room to avoid the sudden pouring of students into the halls, Kuai had a sneaking suspicion that he still had a little more work to do with the pendant before he could go home.

Kuai sat at his desk, shuffling through his papers, makings sure everything was ready for school tomorrow. As he did so, he listened to the sounds of the students in the halls, yelling and celebrating that the first day of school was finally over. He chuckled and shook his head. "If only they knew how easy they have it now…"

A sudden knocking at the door interrupted his thoughts - a rather loud one, Kuai thought. He looked up and saw a wide, metallic grin as Tyler slowly stepped into the room. "Mr. Tao?" he asked. "Is it all right if I come in? I mean, you did say earlier that--"

Kuai immediately rose to his feet. "Of course, Tyler!" he exclaimed. "Come on in!" He was secretly relieved that Tyler had remembered to stop on by, as he knew that kids with ADHD tended to forget their commitments. He crossed around to the front of his desk, leaning against it slightly, making sure not to put all his weight on it.

For his part, Tyler stood walked up to stand in front of Kuai. "Thanks," he sighed in relief. "Today's been just--" He stopped, closed his eyes and shook his head. Kuai could tell his cheeks were flushed -- the kid was definitely overexerted from the day, probably over-stimulated due to a combination of not being medicated along with it being a the first day of the school year. A little bit of sweat was starting to bead up on his forehead, but Tyler quickly wiped it away. "I guess it's hard to understand," he finally said, finally looking the teacher in the eye. Kuai could tell that again he was fighting back tears.

"No," Kuai said, resisting the urge to place his hand on Tyler's shoulder, "I get it. The first day is a lot to take in for anyone, a lot to get adjusted to. Anyone would be justified in feeling a little frustrated at that."

"Maybe," Tyler said, slumping down a little. "I just don't think there's that many people out there who can relate to me. I mean, none of the other kids here at the school have any clue how hard it is to stand out so much like I do."

"You mean like we do," Kuai corrected, a warm look in his eyes.

This caused the corners of Tyler's lips to rise a little. "Yeah. Like we do. I guess you have a lot to teach me about how to deal with being so big."

Perhaps, Kuai thought to himself. As he did so, though, another thought came to his mind. Maybe, just maybe, he should explain the pendant to Tyler. After all, with the kid's overactive imagination, he'd probably have no problem believing him. And besides, it might help him feel better about the situation. Then, if he truly wanted, Kuai could change him back to the way he was, though he secretly hoped it wouldn't come to that.

But would telling someone else about the pendant really be a good idea? Kuai trusted Tyler enough, but after all, they had only known each other for a few hours. And what if there were any unforeseen complications with somebody else knowing? Kuai probably should put the pendant through some more tests before telling anyone else about it. At least, that would be the safe thing to do.

After a moment, Kuai realized that the room had grown silent, and Tyler was staring at him curiously. "Hmm," the boy mused, "You look like you have something to tell me."

Kuai shifted, slightly nervous. "Uhhh…"

"It's okay," Tyler shrugged. "I mean, if it's a secret or something I don't have to know." But as his eyes widened and he started fidgeting slightly, Kuai could tell that Tyler was dying to find out what Kuai was hiding.

"Well…" Kuai started, unsure of exactly what to say.

Kuai took a deep breath, deciding that being open and forthright was the best idea here, even though it might cause some problems, at least in the short term. Besides, he reasoned in the back of his mind, if things got horribly out of hand, he could always use the pendant to change things back, right?

"Okay, Tyler," he said, crossing his arms. "You're right. I do have something I'd like to share with you. You're probably not going to believe me."

Tyler grinned, shaking his head. "Don't worry about that, Mr. Tao. I trust you."

Kuai felt himself smiling in return, glad to hear those words escaping from Tyler's lips yet for some reason also terrified about what they represented. Pushing as many pessimistic thoughts out of his mind as he could, he continued. "Well, Tyler, I'm glad that you do trust me, but this is going to sound completely insane. Anyways…" He hesitated, finally deciding he'd been beating around the bush too much. "You know how one of the first things we bonded on today was the fact that we were both so tall?"

"Yeah!" Tyler nodded enthusiastically. "Up until today I don't think I've ever met someone as tall as I am. It's kinda cool to see that other normal people can be this big."

Kuai gulped. "Well, Tyler, up until a few hours ago, you yourself weren't that big."

He stopped, trying to judge Tyler's reaction, but all he got was a blank, confused stare. "What?" Tyler finally responded. "What do you mean?"

"When I first saw you this morning," Kuai continued, "you were the same height as any of my other students. On the short side, actually." He pulled the pendant out from where it was hiding underneath his shirt. "I actually was able to change you, make you bigger, using this."

Tyler's eyes went wide as he looked at the pendant. "What is that?!" Kuai could tell he had piqued the boy's interest for sure, but he couldn't tell if Tyler was getting excited or angry.

"It's a pendant that my friend sent me. It has some sort of extremely fancy technology involving nanites, which can change the physical properties of things."

Tyler stepped closer to Kuai, trying to see the pendant in greater detail. "Wow, nanites? Really? I've read some about those, how they might be used to terraform other planets and stuff, but I had no idea that they actually existed yet, or were capable of anything like this!"

As he watched the boy get more and more enthusiastic, Kuai inwardly breathed a sigh of relief. This seemed to confirm his decision to share the truth with Tyler, and hopefully would bring the two of them closer together. How close, Kuai thought, was still to be seen.

"But wait!" Tyler exclaimed, a slight doubt forming on his face. "If that were true, why would I have the memories of being big like this for my whole life?"

"Well," Kuai wrinkled his nose, "that's something I'm not entirely sure of yet. Nick -- that's my friend who sent this to me -- says that the nanites can travel back in time and change history. I don't really have a clue exactly how, but what's happened so far seems to line up with what he said."

"Ahhh," Tyler murmured to himself, slowly nodding in understanding. "Wow! That's really cool, Mr. Tao."

"I'm glad you think so, Tyler," Kuai said as he smiled. "I was half-afraid you'd freak out or get mad at me or something."

Grinning again, Tyler stepped a little closer to Kuai. "Me get mad at you? Never!!" He found himself starting to give Kuai a playful punch in the arm, but stopped halfway, realizing he was still talking to a teacher. For a moment, he stood there awkwardly, holding his hand in mid-air, until he finally placed it against Kuai's arm, giving it a friendly pat. "Heheh," Tyler blushed in embarrassment. "Sorry 'bout that, Mr. Tao."

"Don't think twice about it, Tyler. And please, call me Kuai." He didn't quite know why he suddenly blurted that out. He'd never really let any of his students be on a first-name basis with him before. But something was different about Tyler. Even though they had just met, he already felt like the boy was closer to him than just a student. It was a dangerous path to go down, Kuai realized, but something just felt right about it.

"Okay… Kuai." Tyler grinned, and then leaned against the desk next to Kuai, crossing his arms in much the same manner. "I do have one thing I just gotta ask though," he said after a moment.

Kuai turned his head slightly. "What's that, Tyler?"

"Welllll…"
